					<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading mw-first-heading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Prime Minister of Australia</span></h1>
							
<div id="p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown mw-portlet mw-portlet-lang"  >
	<input type="checkbox" id="p-lang-btn-checkbox" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox mw-interlanguage-selector" aria-label="Go to an article in another language. Available in 58 languages"   >

</div></div>
					
					
					<div id="mw-content-text" class="mw-body-content"><div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" lang="en" dir="ltr"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Head of government of Australia</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">For a list of officeholders, see <a href="/wiki/List_of_prime_ministers_of_Australia" title="List of prime ministers of Australia">List of prime ministers of Australia</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">


</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1217818304">.mw-parser-output .infobox-subbox{padding:0;border:none;margin:-3px;width:auto;min-width:100%;font-size:100%;clear:none;float:none;background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .infobox-3cols-child{margin:auto}.mw-parser-output .infobox .navbar{font-size:100%}body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-header,body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-subheader,body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-above,body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-title,body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-image,body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-full-data,body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-below{text-align:center}html.skin-theme-clientpref-night .mw-parser-output .infobox-full-data *{background:#1f1f23!important;color:#f8f9fa}@media(prefers-color-scheme:dark){html.skin-theme-clientpref-os .mw-parser-output .infobox-full-data *{background:#1f1f23!important;color:#f8f9fa}}</style><table class="infobox"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" class="infobox-above" style="font-size: 125%;">Prime Minister of Australia</th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" class="infobox-image" style="padding-bottom:0.4em; <ul><li>Prime Minister (informal)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/The_Honourable" title="The Honourable">The Honourable</a><sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> (formal)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Excellency" title="Excellency">His Excellency</a><sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> (diplomatic)</li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Status</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">Head of government</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Member of</th><td class="infobox-data"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1126788409"><div class="plainlist">

<li><a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Australia" title="Cabinet of Australia">Cabinet</a></li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Reports to</th><td class="infobox-data"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1129693374">.mw-parser-output .hlist dl,.mw-parser-output ol>li:first-child::before,.mw-parser-output .hlist dt ol>li:first-child::before,.mw-parser-output .hlist li ol>li:first-child::before{content:" ("counter(listitem)"\a0 "}</style><div <ul><li><a href="/wiki/The_Lodge_(Australia)" class="mw-redirect" title="The Lodge (Australia)">The Lodge</a> (primary)</li>

</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><a href="/wiki/Seat_(legal_entity)" title="Seat (legal entity)">Seat</a></th><td class="infobox-data">Office of the Prime Minister, <a href="/wiki/Parliament_House,_Canberra" title="Parliament House, Canberra">Parliament House</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Appointer</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Governor-General_of_Australia" title="Governor-General of Australia">Governor-General</a><sup id="cite_ref-APMC-PM_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-APMC-PM-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> (according to the wishes of the House of Representatives)</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Formation</th><td class="infobox-data">1&#160;January 1901<span class="noprint">&#59;&#32;123 years ago</span><span style="display:none">&#160;(<span class="bday dtstart published updated">1901-01-01</span>)</span><sup id="cite_ref-APMC-PM_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-APMC-PM-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">First holder</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Edmund_Barton" title="Edmund Barton">Edmund Barton</a><sup id="cite_ref-APMC-PM_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-APMC-PM-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Deputy</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Deputy_Prime_Minister_of_Australia" title="Deputy Prime Minister of Australia">Deputy Prime Minister</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Salary</th><td class="infobox-data">$586,930 (2023)<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Website</th><td class="infobox-data"><span class="url"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://pm.gov.au">pm<wbr />.gov<wbr />.au</a></span></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The <b>prime minister of Australia</b> is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Australia" class="mw-redirect" title="Commonwealth of Australia">Commonwealth of Australia</a>. By virtue of holding the <a href="/wiki/Confidence_and_supply" title="Confidence and supply">confidence</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Australian_House_of_Representatives" title="Australian House of Representatives">House of Representatives</a> (generally through leading the parliamentary party with a majority of seats), they chair the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Australia" title="Cabinet of Australia">Cabinet</a> and thus head the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Government" title="Australian Government">federal executive government</a>. The prime minister and their party also generally hold predominant legislative influence through their numbers in <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Australia" title="Parliament of Australia">Parliament</a>. 
</p><p>The current prime minister is <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Albanese" title="Anthony Albanese">Anthony Albanese</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Labor_Party" title="Australian Labor Party">Australian Labor Party</a>, who assumed the office on 23 May 2022.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Formally appointed by the <a href="/wiki/Governor-General_of_Australia" title="Governor-General of Australia">governor-general</a>, the role and duties of the prime minister are not described by the <a href="/wiki/Australian_constitution" class="mw-redirect" title="Australian constitution">Australian constitution</a> but rather defined by <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_convention_(political_custom)" title="Constitutional convention (political custom)">constitutional convention</a> deriving from the <a href="/wiki/Westminster_system" title="Westminster system">Westminster system</a> and <a href="/wiki/Responsible_government" title="Responsible government">responsible government</a>. Prime ministers do not have a <a href="/wiki/Term_of_office" title="Term of office">set duration</a> or <a href="/wiki/Term_limits" class="mw-redirect" title="Term limits">number of terms</a>, but an individual's term generally ends when their political party loses a <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Australia" title="Elections in Australia">federal election</a>, or they lose or relinquish the leadership of their party.
</p><p>The office of prime minister comes with various privileges, including the use of two official residences: <a href="/wiki/The_Lodge_(Australia)" class="mw-redirect" title="The Lodge (Australia)">The Lodge</a> in <a href="/wiki/Canberra" title="Canberra">Canberra</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kirribilli_House" title="Kirribilli House">Kirribilli House</a> in <a href="/wiki/Sydney" title="Sydney">Sydney</a>, as well as an office at <a href="/wiki/Parliament_House,_Canberra" title="Parliament House, Canberra">Parliament House</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/List_of_prime_ministers_of_Australia" title="List of prime ministers of Australia">Thirty-one people</a> (thirty men and one woman) have served as prime minister, the first of whom was <a href="/wiki/Edmund_Barton" title="Edmund Barton">Edmund Barton</a> taking office on 1 January 1901 following <a href="/wiki/Federation_of_Australia" title="Federation of Australia">federation of the British colonies in Australia</a>. The <a href="/wiki/List_of_prime_ministers_of_Australia_by_time_in_office" title="List of prime ministers of Australia by time in office">longest-serving</a> prime minister was <a href="/wiki/Robert_Menzies" title="Robert Menzies">Robert Menzies</a>, who served over 18 years, and the shortest-serving was <a href="/wiki/Frank_Forde" title="Frank Forde">Frank Forde</a>, who served one week. 
</p>
<meta property="mw:PageProp/toc" />
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Powers_and_responsibilities">Powers and responsibilities</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Prime_Minister_of_Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Powers and responsibilities"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>In common with other political systems based on the <a href="/wiki/Westminster_system" title="Westminster system">Westminster system</a>, the prime minister both leads the <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">executive government</a> and wields significant power in <a href="/wiki/Parliament" title="Parliament">Parliament</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Executive_role">Executive role</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Prime_Minister_of_Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Executive role"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Australia" title="Cabinet of Australia">Cabinet</a>, the primary decision making body of the executive government, is chaired by the prime minister. While the prime minister has been described as the "first among equals" of the other ministers that make up cabinet, they nevertheless wield primary influence in the body. They set the agenda and processes of cabinet meetings and has the final word where a collective decision cannot be reached. Ministers making up the cabinet are chosen by the prime minister and may be removed at any time. Additionally, the prime minister chooses the portfolio of each minister and a prime minister's resignation or dismissal leads by convention to the resignation of all other ministers.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEElder201861–3_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEElder201861–3-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup> The precise authority of each individual prime minister within cabinet is uncertain, as their deliberations are secret, however in recent decades their power has increased substantially. The authority of the prime minister to make independent policy decisions apart from Cabinet is also present, which such decisions also colloquially called "captain's calls".<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup> The prime minister also has significant influence in the setting of foreign policy, through their role as chair of the <a href="/wiki/National_Security_Committee_(Australia)" title="National Security Committee (Australia)">National Security Committee</a>, a sub-committee of cabinet whose decisions do not need to be endorsed by the cabinet as a whole.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_the_Prime_Minister_and_Cabinet202242_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_the_Prime_Minister_and_Cabinet202242-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The prime minister is also the responsible minister for the <a href="/wiki/Department_of_the_Prime_Minister_and_Cabinet_(Australia)" title="Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet (Australia)">Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet</a>, whose tasks include general policy development across the government, inter-governmental communications, honours and symbols policy and Indigenous government programmes.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> 
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Legislative_role">Legislative role</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Prime_Minister_of_Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Legislative role"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Since the emergence of the strong party system in Australia in the 1920s, prime ministers have almost always been the head of the <a href="/wiki/Political_party" title="Political party">party</a> of coalition of parties that has a majority in the House of Representatives (which has been either the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Labor_Party" title="Australian Labor Party">Labor Party</a> or the <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Party_of_Australia" title="Liberal Party of Australia">Liberal Party</a> since the 1940s). <a href="/wiki/Responsible_government" title="Responsible government">Responsible government</a> has always required the prime minister and government to have the confidence of a majority of the lower house in order to govern, however the emergence of strong parties with members strongly punished for voting against party policy (also known as <a href="/wiki/Crossing_the_floor" title="Crossing the floor">crossing the floor</a>) has meant that most prime ministers and governments have significant control over the passage of bills in this house. However, bills must also be passed by the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Senate" title="Australian Senate">Senate</a> (the upper house) in order to become law and the government rarely has a majority in this house, leading to some checks on the legislative powers of the government. The prime minister also controls the date of elections, through formal advice to the governor-general, with such elections usually occurring within a 6 month period prior to the maximum 3 year term of the House of Representatives expiring. 
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_responsibilities">Other responsibilities</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Prime_Minister_of_Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Other responsibilities"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/National_Cabinet_(Australia)" title="National Cabinet (Australia)">National Cabinet</a>, the primary inter-governmental decision making forum between the federal government and the states, is also chaired by the prime minister.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup> While called a cabinet, the body is merely a discussion forum and the principles of secrecy and collective decision making do not apply.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup> 
</p><p>Since the 1940s, the prime minister has asserted their authority to select the governor-general alone, instead of this being a cabinet decision.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> The power is exercised through advice to the <a href="/wiki/King_of_Australia" class="mw-redirect" title="King of Australia">King of Australia</a>, who holds the de jure power to make the appointment and is by convention bound to accept such advice. The prime minister can also advise the monarch to dismiss the governor-general, though it remains unclear how quickly the monarch would act on such advice in a <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_crisis" title="Constitutional crisis">constitutional crisis</a>. This uncertainty, and the possibility of a "race" between the governor-general and prime minister to dismiss the other, was a key question in the <a href="/wiki/1975_Australian_constitutional_crisis" title="1975 Australian constitutional crisis">1975 constitutional crisis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> 
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Selection_and_constitutional_basis">Selection and constitutional basis</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Prime_Minister_of_Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Selection and constitutional basis"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1129693374"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1045330069">.mw-parser-output href="/wiki/Tasmania" title="Tasmania"><img alt="Tasmania" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Flag_of_Tasmania.svg/23px-Flag_of_Tasmania.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="12" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Flag_of_Tasmania.svg/35px-Flag_of_Tasmania.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Flag_of_Tasmania.svg/46px-Flag_of_Tasmania.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="600" /></a></span></span> <a href="/wiki/Category:Tasmania" title="Category:Tasmania">Tasmania</a></span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="center" style="width:auto; margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;"><div style="font-size:85%;"><div class="hlist"><ul><li><span class="flagicon"><span class="mw-image-border" typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/Australian_Capital_Territory" title="Australian Capital Territory"><img alt="Australian Capital Territory" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Flag_of_the_Australian_Capital_Territory.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Australian_Capital_Territory.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="12" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Flag_of_the_Australian_Capital_Territory.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_Australian_Capital_Territory.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Flag_of_the_Australian_Capital_Territory.svg/46px-Flag_of_the_Australian_Capital_Territory.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="600" /></a></span></span> <a href="/wiki/Category:Australian_Capital_Territory" title="Category:Australian Capital Territory">Australian Capital Territory</a></li><li><span class="nowrap"><span class="flagicon"><span class="mw-image-border" typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/Northern_Territory" title="Northern Territory"><img alt="Northern Territory" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Flag_of_the_Northern_Territory.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Northern_Territory.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="12" class="mw-file-element" //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Flag_of_the_Northern_Territory.svg/46px-Flag_of_the_Northern_Territory.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="600" /></a></span></span><a href="/wiki/Category:Northern_Territory" title="Category:Northern Territory">Northern Territory</a></span></li></ul></div></div></div></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1129693374"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1063604349">.mw-parser-output .navbar{display:inline;font-size:88%;font-weight:normal}.mw-parser-output .navbar-collapse{float:left;text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .navbar-boxtext{word-spacing:0}.mw-parser-output .navbar ul{display:inline-block;white-space:nowrap;line-height:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::before{margin-right:-0.125em;content:"[ "}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::after{margin-left:-0.125em;content:" ]"}.mw-parser-output .navbar li{word-spacing:-0.125em}.mw-parser-output .navbar a>span,.mw-parser-output .navbar a>abbr{text-decoration:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-mini abbr{font-variant:small-caps;border-bottom:none;text-decoration:none;cursor:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-full{font-size:114%;margin:0 7em}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-mini{font-size:114%;margin:0 4em}</style><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Politics_of_Australia_sidebar" title="Template:Politics of Australia sidebar"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Politics_of_Australia_sidebar" title="Template talk:Politics of Australia sidebar"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a href="/wiki/Special:EditPage/Template:Politics_of_Australia_sidebar" title="Special:EditPage/Template:Politics of Australia sidebar"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Australian_House_of_Reps_1901.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Australian_House_of_Reps_1901.jpg/220px-Australian_House_of_Reps_1901.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Australian_House_of_Reps_1901.jpg/330px-Australian_House_of_Reps_1901.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Australian_House_of_Reps_1901.jpg/440px-Australian_House_of_Reps_1901.jpg 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="449" /></a><figcaption>Australia's first prime minister, <a href="/wiki/Edmund_Barton" title="Edmund Barton">Edmund Barton</a>, at the central table in the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Representatives_(Australia)" class="mw-redirect" title="House of Representatives (Australia)">House of Representatives</a> in 1901.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In ordinary circumstances, the leader of the party or coalition that has the confidence of the House of Representatives is entitled to become prime minister and form a government. Generally, a party or coalition will have a majority in the lower house in order to provide confidence, however in periods of minority government, the larger party will rely on confidence and supply from minor parties or independents. By convention, the prime minister must be a member of the lower house.<sup id="cite_ref-senatebrief14_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-senatebrief14-17">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup> The only case where a member of the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Senate" title="Australian Senate">Senate</a> was appointed prime minister was <a href="/wiki/John_Gorton" title="John Gorton">John Gorton</a>, who subsequently resigned his Senate position and was <a href="/wiki/1968_Higgins_by-election" title="1968 Higgins by-election">elected</a> as the <a href="/wiki/Division_of_Higgins" title="Division of Higgins">member for Higgins</a> in the House of Representatives. The prime minister is formally appointed to the role by the governor-general under section 64 of the Australian Constitution, however their choice is limited in normal circumstances to the individual with the confidence of the lower house. However, the prime minister (and all other ministers) must be a parliamentarians or become one within three months to be a minister. 
</p><p>There are no term limits for the prime minister, and they are generally entitled to continue in their role whilst they retain the confidence of the lower house. Individuals most commonly cease to become prime minister after losing an election by not obtaining a majority in the lower house (at which point they generally become leader of the opposition or resign) or through replacement by their parliamentary party colleagues. This later method has become increasingly common, with the office changing hands four times due to parliamentary spill and only twice due to an election in the period following the election defeat of John Howard in 2007 to the election of Anthony Albanese in 2022. 
</p><p>A prime minister may also lose their position following a vote of no confidence in the government or due to a failure to pass supply through the lower house. In either event, the prime minister is required by convention to either resign or call an election. Whether a prime minister is required to resign or call an election following an inability to pass supply through the Senate was the animating issue of the <a href="/wiki/1975_Australian_constitutional_crisis" title="1975 Australian constitutional crisis">1975 constitutional crisis</a>. In that event, governor-general Sir John Kerr dismissed the Whitlam government following the deferral of the Senate of the government's budget and their demand that they would not pass supply until the government called an election. The constitutional propriety of the governor-general's action during that period remains subject to vigorous debate.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>
Despite the importance of the office of prime minister, the Constitution does not mention the office by name. The conventions of the <a href="/wiki/Westminster_system" title="Westminster system">Westminster system</a> were thought to be sufficiently entrenched in Australia by the authors of the Constitution that it was deemed unnecessary to detail these.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup> Indeed, prior to Federation in 1901 the terms "premier" and "prime minister" were used interchangeably for the head of government in a colony.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup></p><figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:John_Gorton_Swearing_In.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/John_Gorton_Swearing_In.jpg/220px-John_Gorton_Swearing_In.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="218" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/John_Gorton_Swearing_In.jpg/330px-John_Gorton_Swearing_In.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/9b/John_Gorton_Swearing_In.jpg 2x" data-file-width="425" data-file-height="421" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/John_Gorton" title="John Gorton">John Gorton</a> being sworn in as the 19th Prime Minister on 10 January 1968. To date, Gorton is the only Senator to have served as Prime Minister, though he would swiftly move to the House of Representatives as the member for <a href="/wiki/Division_of_Higgins" title="Division of Higgins">Higgins</a>.</figcaption></figure><p>Following a resignation in other circumstances or the death of a prime minister, the governor-general generally appoints the <a href="/wiki/Deputy_Prime_Minister_of_Australia" title="Deputy Prime Minister of Australia">deputy prime minister</a> as the new prime minister, until or if such time as the governing party or senior coalition party elects an alternative party leader. This has resulted in the party leaders from the Country Party (now named National Party) being appointed as prime minister, despite being the smaller party of their coalition. This occurred when <a href="/wiki/Earle_Page" title="Earle Page">Earle Page</a> became caretaker prime minister following the death of <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Lyons" title="Joseph Lyons">Joseph Lyons</a> in 1939, and when <a href="/wiki/John_McEwen" title="John McEwen">John McEwen</a> became caretaker prime minister following the <a href="/wiki/Disappearance_of_Harold_Holt" title="Disappearance of Harold Holt">disappearance of Harold Holt</a> in 1967. However, in 1941, <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Fadden" title="Arthur Fadden">Arthur Fadden</a> became the leader of the Coalition and subsequently prime minister by the agreement of both coalition parties, despite being the leader of the smaller party in coalition, following the resignation of UAP leader Robert Menzies.
</p><p>Excluding the brief transition periods during changes of government or leadership elections, there have only been a handful of cases where someone other than the leader of the majority party in the House of Representatives was prime minister:
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Federation_of_Australia" title="Federation of Australia">Federation</a> occurred on 1 January 1901, but <a href="/wiki/1901_Australian_federal_election" title="1901 Australian federal election">elections for the first parliament</a> were not scheduled until late March. In the interim, an unelected <a href="/wiki/Caretaker_government" title="Caretaker government">caretaker government</a> was necessary. In what is now known as the <a href="/wiki/Hopetoun_Blunder" title="Hopetoun Blunder">Hopetoun Blunder</a>, the governor-general, <a href="/wiki/John_Hope,_7th_Earl_of_Hopetoun" title="John Hope, 7th Earl of Hopetoun">Lord Hopetoun</a>, invited Sir <a href="/wiki/William_Lyne" title="William Lyne">William Lyne</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Premier_of_New_South_Wales" title="Premier of New South Wales">premier</a> of the most populous state, <a href="/wiki/New_South_Wales" title="New South Wales">New South Wales</a>, to form a government. Lyne was unable to do so and returned his commission in favour of <a href="/wiki/Edmund_Barton" title="Edmund Barton">Edmund Barton</a>, who became the first prime minister and led the inaugural government into and beyond the election.</li>
<li>During the second parliament, three parties (Free Trade, Protectionist and Labor) had roughly equal representation in the House of Representatives. The leaders of the three parties, <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Deakin" title="Alfred Deakin">Alfred Deakin</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_Reid" title="George Reid">George Reid</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chris_Watson" title="Chris Watson">Chris Watson</a> each served as prime minister before losing a vote of confidence.</li>
<li>As a result of the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Labor_Party_split_of_1916" title="Australian Labor Party split of 1916">Labor Party's split over conscription</a>, <a href="/wiki/Billy_Hughes" title="Billy Hughes">Billy Hughes</a> and his supporters were expelled from the Labor Party in November 1916. He subsequently continued on as prime minister at the head of the new <a href="/wiki/National_Labor_Party" title="National Labor Party">National Labor Party</a>, which had only 14 members out of a total of 75 in the House of Representatives. The <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_Liberal_Party" class="mw-redirect" title="Commonwealth Liberal Party">Commonwealth Liberal Party</a> – despite still forming the official Opposition – provided confidence and supply until February 1917, when the two parties agreed to merge and formed the <a href="/wiki/Nationalist_Party_(Australia)" title="Nationalist Party (Australia)">Nationalist Party</a>.</li>
<li>During the <a href="/wiki/1975_Australian_constitutional_crisis" title="1975 Australian constitutional crisis">1975 constitutional crisis</a>, on 11 November 1975, the governor-general, Sir <a href="/wiki/John_Kerr_(governor-general)" title="John Kerr (governor-general)">John Kerr</a>, dismissed the Labor Party's <a href="/wiki/Gough_Whitlam" title="Gough Whitlam">Gough Whitlam</a> as prime minister. Despite Labor holding a majority in the House of Representatives, Kerr appointed the Leader of the Opposition, <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Party_of_Australia" title="Liberal Party of Australia">Liberal</a> leader <a href="/wiki/Malcolm_Fraser" title="Malcolm Fraser">Malcolm Fraser</a> as caretaker prime minister, conditional on the passage of the Whitlam government's <a href="/wiki/Confidence_and_supply" title="Confidence and supply">Supply</a> bills through the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Senate" title="Australian Senate">Senate</a> and the calling of an election for both houses of parliament. Fraser accepted these terms and immediately advised a <a href="/wiki/Double_dissolution" title="Double dissolution">double dissolution</a>. An election was called for <a href="/wiki/1975_Australian_federal_election" title="1975 Australian federal election">13 December</a>, which the Liberal Party won in its own right (although the Liberals governed in a coalition with the Country Party).</li></ul>
<p>Compared to other <a href="/wiki/Westminster_system" title="Westminster system">Westminster systems</a> such as those of <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">Canada</a>'s federal and provincial governments, the transition from an outgoing prime minister to an incoming prime minister has been brief in Australia since the 1970s. Prior to that, in accordance with longstanding Australian constitutional practice, convention held that an outgoing prime minister would stay on as a caretaker until the full election results were tallied. Starting with the <a href="/wiki/1972_Australian_federal_election" title="1972 Australian federal election">1972 Australian federal election</a> on 2 December 1972, Gough Whitlam and his deputy were sworn in on 5 December 1972 to form an interim government for two weeks, as the vote was being finalised and the full ministry makeup was being determined. In 2022 <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Albanese" title="Anthony Albanese">Anthony Albanese</a> became prime minister on 23 May which was two days after the <a href="/wiki/2022_Australian_federal_election" title="2022 Australian federal election">2022 Australian federal election</a> where his party won a majority in the <a href="/wiki/Australian_House_of_Representatives" title="Australian House of Representatives">House</a>, with Albanese and four senior cabinet ministers being sworn into an interim ministry,<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup> when the results of the election were more clearly known the entire ministry was sworn in on 1 June 2022.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Amenities_of_office">Amenities of office</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Prime_Minister_of_Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Amenities of office"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Salary">Salary</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Prime_Minister_of_Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Salary"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>

</tbody></table>
<p>As of 27&#160;August&#160;2023,<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Prime_Minister_of_Australia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup> Australia's prime minister is paid a total salary of <span style="white-space: nowrap">A$586,950</span>.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup> This is made up of the 'base salary' received by all members of parliament (<span style="white-space: nowrap">A$225,750<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup></span>) plus a 160 percent 'additional salary' for the role of prime minister.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup> Increases in the base salary of MPs and senators are determined annually by the independent Remuneration Tribunal.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_31-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-31">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Residences_and_transport">Residences and transport</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Prime_Minister_of_Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Residences and transport"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<figure class="mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Curtin_GGPrinceHenry_Fadden_Hughes_Menzies.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Curtin_GGPrinceHenry_Fadden_Hughes_Menzies.jpg/200px-Curtin_GGPrinceHenry_Fadden_Hughes_Menzies.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="148" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Curtin_GGPrinceHenry_Fadden_Hughes_Menzies.jpg/300px-Curtin_GGPrinceHenry_Fadden_Hughes_Menzies.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Curtin_GGPrinceHenry_Fadden_Hughes_Menzies.jpg/400px-Curtin_GGPrinceHenry_Fadden_Hughes_Menzies.jpg 2x" data-file-width="931" data-file-height="687" /></a><figcaption>Prime ministers <a href="/wiki/John_Curtin" title="John Curtin">Curtin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Fadden" title="Arthur Fadden">Fadden</a>, <a href="/wiki/Billy_Hughes" title="Billy Hughes">Hughes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Menzies" title="Robert Menzies">Menzies</a> and Governor-General <a href="/wiki/Prince_Henry,_Duke_of_Gloucester" title="Prince Henry, Duke of Gloucester">The Duke of Gloucester</a> 2nd from left, in 1945.</figcaption></figure>
<p>While in office, the prime minister has two official residences. The primary official residence is <a href="/wiki/The_Lodge_(Australia)" class="mw-redirect" title="The Lodge (Australia)">the Lodge</a> in <a href="/wiki/Canberra" title="Canberra">Canberra</a>. Most prime ministers have chosen the Lodge as their primary residence because of its security facilities and close proximity to Parliament House. There have been some exceptions, however. <a href="/wiki/James_Scullin" title="James Scullin">James Scullin</a> preferred to live at the <a href="/wiki/Hotel_Canberra" title="Hotel Canberra">Hotel Canberra</a> (now the Hyatt Hotel) and <a href="/wiki/Ben_Chifley" title="Ben Chifley">Ben Chifley</a> lived in the <a href="/wiki/Hotel_Kurrajong" title="Hotel Kurrajong">Hotel Kurrajong</a>. More recently, <a href="/wiki/John_Howard" title="John Howard">John Howard</a> used the <a href="/wiki/Sydney" title="Sydney">Sydney</a> prime ministerial residence, <a href="/wiki/Kirribilli_House" title="Kirribilli House">Kirribilli House</a>, as his primary accommodation. On her appointment on 24 June 2010, <a href="/wiki/Julia_Gillard" title="Julia Gillard">Julia Gillard</a> said she would not be living in the Lodge until such time as she was returned to office by popular vote at the <a href="/wiki/2010_Australian_federal_election" title="2010 Australian federal election">next general election</a>, as she became prime minister by replacing an incumbent during a parliamentary term. <a href="/wiki/Tony_Abbott" title="Tony Abbott">Tony Abbott</a> was never able to occupy the Lodge during his term (2013–15) because it was undergoing extensive renovations, which continued into the early part of his successor <a href="/wiki/Malcolm_Turnbull" title="Malcolm Turnbull">Malcolm Turnbull</a>'s term.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup> Instead, Abbott resided in dedicated rooms at the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Federal_Police" title="Australian Federal Police">Australian Federal Police College</a> when in Canberra.
</p><p>During his first term, Rudd had a staff at the Lodge consisting of a senior chef and an assistant chef, a child carer, one senior house attendant, and two junior house attendants. At <a href="/wiki/Kirribilli_House" title="Kirribilli House">Kirribilli House</a> in Sydney, there are a full-time chef and a full-time house attendant.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup>
The official residences are fully staffed and catered for both the prime minister and their family. In addition, both have extensive security facilities. These residences are regularly used for official entertaining, such as receptions for <a href="/wiki/Australian_of_the_Year" title="Australian of the Year">Australian of the Year</a> finalists.
</p><p>The prime minister receives a number of transport amenities for official business. The <a href="/wiki/Royal_Australian_Air_Force" title="Royal Australian Air Force">Royal Australian Air Force</a>'s Airbus A330 MRTT, or KC30-A, transports the prime minister within Australia and overseas.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup> The call-sign for the aircraft is "Envoy". For ground travel, the prime minister is transported in an armoured <a href="/wiki/BMW" title="BMW">BMW</a> 7 Series model. It is referred to as "C-1", or Commonwealth One, because of its number plate. It is escorted by police vehicles from state and federal authorities.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed" style="text-align: center;">
	<li class="gallerycaption">Privileges of office</li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 242px">
			<div class="thumb" style="width: 240px;"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Lodge_Canberra_renovated.jpg" class="mw-file-description" title="The Lodge"><img alt="The Lodge" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/The_Lodge_Canberra_renovated.jpg/360px-The_Lodge_Canberra_renovated.jpg" decoding="async" width="240" height="120" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/The_Lodge_Canberra_renovated.jpg/540px-The_Lodge_Canberra_renovated.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/The_Lodge_Canberra_renovated.jpg/720px-The_Lodge_Canberra_renovated.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="400" /></a></span></div>

			<div class="gallerytext"><b><a href="/wiki/No._34_Squadron_RAAF" title="No. 34 Squadron RAAF">Official aircraft</a></b></div>
		</li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="After_office">After office</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Prime_Minister_of_Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: After office"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Politicians, including prime ministers, are usually granted certain privileges after leaving office, such as office accommodation, staff assistance, and a Life Gold Pass which entitles the holder to travel within Australia for non-commercial purposes at government expense. In 2017, then prime minister Malcolm Turnbull said the pass should be available only to former prime ministers, though he would not use it when he was no longer PM.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Only one prime minister who had left the Federal Parliament ever returned. <a href="/wiki/Stanley_Bruce" title="Stanley Bruce">Stanley Bruce</a> was defeated in his own seat in <a href="/wiki/1929_Australian_federal_election" title="1929 Australian federal election">1929</a> while prime minister but was re-elected to parliament in <a href="/wiki/1931_Australian_federal_election" title="1931 Australian federal election">1931</a>. Other prime ministers were elected to parliaments other than the Australian federal parliament: Sir <a href="/wiki/George_Reid" title="George Reid">George Reid</a> was elected to the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Commons_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="House of Commons of the United Kingdom">UK House of Commons</a> (after his term as High Commissioner to the UK), and <a href="/wiki/Frank_Forde" title="Frank Forde">Frank Forde</a> was re-elected to the Queensland Parliament (after his term as High Commissioner to Canada, and a failed attempt to re-enter the Federal Parliament).
</p><p>As well as Reid and Forde, five other prime ministers went on to hold diplomatic posts.
</p><p>Andrew Fisher, Joseph Cook and Stanley Bruce also served as High Commissioners to the United Kingdom, Gough Whitlam had served as Ambassador to UNESCO and Kevin Rudd is currently the Ambassador to the United States.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Acting_prime_ministers_and_succession">Acting prime ministers and succession</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Prime_Minister_of_Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Acting prime ministers and succession"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Deputy_Prime_Minister_of_Australia" title="Deputy Prime Minister of Australia">deputy prime minister</a> becomes <a href="/wiki/Acting_prime_minister" title="Acting prime minister">acting prime minister</a> if the prime minister is unable to undertake the role for a short time, for example if they are ill, overseas or on leave (and if both are unavailable, then another senior minister takes on this role).<sup id="cite_ref-:02_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:02-42">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup> The <i>Acts Interpretation Act 1901</i> confers upon acting ministers "the same power and authority with respect to the absent Minister's statutory responsibilities".<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>If the prime minister were to die, then the deputy prime minister would be appointed prime minister by the governor-general until the government votes for another member to be its leader.<sup id="cite_ref-:02_42-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:02-42">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup> This happened when <a href="/wiki/Disappearance_of_Harold_Holt" title="Disappearance of Harold Holt">Harold Holt disappeared</a> in 1967,<sup id="cite_ref-:02_42-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:02-42">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup> when <a href="/wiki/John_McEwen" title="John McEwen">John McEwen</a> was appointed prime minister.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-45">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup> On the other two occasions that the prime minister has died in office, in <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Lyons" title="Joseph Lyons">1939</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_Curtin" title="John Curtin">1945</a>, <a href="/wiki/Earle_Page" title="Earle Page">Earle Page</a> and <a href="/wiki/Frank_Forde" title="Frank Forde">Frank Forde</a>, respectively, were appointed prime minister.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_45-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-45">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the early 20th century, overseas travel generally required long journeys by ship. As a result, some held the position of acting prime minister for significant periods of time, including <a href="/wiki/William_Watt_(Australian_politician)" title="William Watt (Australian politician)">William Watt</a> (16 months, 1918–1919),<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/George_Pearce" title="George Pearce">George Pearce</a> (7 months, 1916),<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Deakin" title="Alfred Deakin">Alfred Deakin</a> (6 months, 1902),<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Cook" title="Joseph Cook">Joseph Cook</a> (5 months, 1921),<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/James_Fenton_(Australian_politician)" class="mw-redirect" title="James Fenton (Australian politician)">James Fenton</a> (19 weeks, 1930–1931),<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">&#91;50&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/John_Forrest" title="John Forrest">John Forrest</a> (4 months, 1907),<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Fadden" title="Arthur Fadden">Arthur Fadden</a> (4 months, 1941). Fadden was acting prime minister for a cumulative total of 676 days (over 22 months) between 1941 and 1958.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Honours">Honours</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Prime_Minister_of_Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Honours"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Prime ministers have been granted numerous honours, typically after their period as prime minister has concluded, with a few exceptions.
</p><p>Nine former prime ministers were awarded knighthoods: Barton (<a href="/wiki/Order_of_St_Michael_and_St_George" title="Order of St Michael and St George">GCMG</a>, 1902),<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">&#91;53&#93;</a></sup> Reid (GCMG, 1911),<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup> Cook (GCMG, 1918),<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup> Page (GCMG, 1938),<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup> Menzies (<a href="/wiki/Order_of_the_Thistle" title="Order of the Thistle">KT</a>, 1963),<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup> Fadden (KCMG, 1951),<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">&#91;58&#93;</a></sup> McEwen (GCMG, 1971),<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup> Gorton (GCMG, 1977),<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup> and McMahon (GCMG, 1977).<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup> Of those awarded, Barton and Menzies were knighted while still serving as prime minister, with Page awarded his before becoming prime minister, and the remainder awarded after leaving office. Reid (<a href="/wiki/Order_of_the_Bath" title="Order of the Bath">GCB</a>, 1916),<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup> Menzies (<a href="/wiki/Knight_of_the_Order_of_Australia" class="mw-redirect" title="Knight of the Order of Australia">AK</a>, 1976)<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">&#91;63&#93;</a></sup> and Fadden (GCMG, 1958)<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">&#91;64&#93;</a></sup> were awarded a second knighthood after leaving office.
</p><p>Non-titular honours were also bestowed on former prime ministers, usually the <a href="/wiki/Order_of_the_Companions_of_Honour" title="Order of the Companions of Honour">Order of the Companions of Honour</a>. This honour was awarded to Bruce (1927),<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">&#91;65&#93;</a></sup> Lyons (1936),<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup> Hughes (1941),<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup> Page (1942),<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">&#91;68&#93;</a></sup> Menzies (1951),<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">&#91;69&#93;</a></sup> Holt (1967),<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup> McEwen (1969),<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup> Gorton (1971),<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup> McMahon (1972),<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">&#91;73&#93;</a></sup> and Fraser (1977),<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">&#91;74&#93;</a></sup> mostly during office as prime minister.
</p><p>In almost all occasions these honours were only accepted by non-Labor/conservative prime ministers. However, appointment to the <a href="/wiki/Privy_Council_of_the_United_Kingdom" class="mw-redirect" title="Privy Council of the United Kingdom">Privy Council of the United Kingdom</a> was accepted by all prime ministers until 1983 (with the exception of Alfred Deakin, Chris Watson and Gough Whitlam), with Malcolm Fraser being the last prime ministerial appointee.
</p><p>Since its introduction in 1975, former prime ministers of Australia have been appointed to the <a href="/wiki/Order_of_Australia" title="Order of Australia">Order of Australia</a> and to its highest level – Companion: Whitlam (1978),<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">&#91;75&#93;</a></sup> Fraser (1988),<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup> Gorton (1988),<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">&#91;77&#93;</a></sup> Howard (2008),<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">&#91;78&#93;</a></sup> Gillard (2017),<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">&#91;79&#93;</a></sup> Rudd (2019),<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">&#91;80&#93;</a></sup> Abbott (2020),<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">&#91;81&#93;</a></sup> and Turnbull (2021).<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">&#91;82&#93;</a></sup> Keating refused appointment in the 1997 Australia Day Honours, saying that he had long believed honours should be reserved for those whose work in the community went unrecognised and that having been Prime Minister was sufficient public recognition.<sup id="cite_ref-naa_afteroffice_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-naa_afteroffice-83">&#91;83&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">&#91;84&#93;</a></sup> Bob Hawke was appointed a Companion in 1979, for service to trade unionism and industrial relations, before becoming prime minister in 1983.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">&#91;85&#93;</a></sup> Menzies was appointed to the higher grade of Knight of the Order, which is no longer awarded, in 1976.
</p><p>John Howard was also appointed to the <a href="/wiki/Order_of_Merit" title="Order of Merit">Order of Merit</a> in 2012, whose appointments are within the personal gift of the monarch.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup> Menzies' <a href="/wiki/Knight_of_the_Order_of_the_Thistle" class="mw-redirect" title="Knight of the Order of the Thistle">Knight of the Order of the Thistle</a> awarding was also in the personal gift of <a href="/wiki/Queen_Elizabeth_II" class="mw-redirect" title="Queen Elizabeth II">Queen Elizabeth II</a> in 1963.
</p><p>Although not strictly an honour, one former prime minister was raised to the peerage; Stanley Bruce was created 1st Viscount Bruce of Melbourne<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">&#91;87&#93;</a></sup> in the <a href="/wiki/1947_New_Year_Honours" title="1947 New Year Honours">1947 New Year Honours</a>.
</p><p>In addition to these honours, all deceased former prime ministers of Australia currently have federal electorates named after them, with the exception of Sir Joseph Cook (a <a href="/wiki/Division_of_Cook" title="Division of Cook">Division of Cook</a> does exist, but it is named after explorer <a href="/wiki/James_Cook" title="James Cook">James Cook</a>). The most newly created of these electorates is the <a href="/wiki/Division_of_Hawke" title="Division of Hawke">Division of Hawke</a>, named in honour of the recently deceased Bob Hawke in 2021.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Lists_relating_to_the_prime_ministers_of_Australia">Lists relating to the prime ministers of Australia</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Prime_Minister_of_Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Lists relating to the prime ministers of Australia"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The longest-serving prime minister was <a href="/wiki/Robert_Menzies" title="Robert Menzies">Robert Menzies</a>, who served in office twice: from 26 April 1939 to 28 August 1941, and again from 19 December 1949 to 26 January 1966. In total Robert Menzies spent 18 years, 5 months and 12 days in office. He served under the United Australia Party and the Liberal Party respectively.
</p><p>The shortest-serving prime minister was <a href="/wiki/Frank_Forde" title="Frank Forde">Frank Forde</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">&#91;88&#93;</a></sup> who was appointed to the position on 6 July 1945 after the death of <a href="/wiki/John_Curtin" title="John Curtin">John Curtin</a>, and served until 13 July 1945 when <a href="/wiki/Ben_Chifley" title="Ben Chifley">Ben Chifley</a> was elected leader of the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Labor_Party" title="Australian Labor Party">Australian Labor Party</a>.
</p><p>The most recent prime minister to serve out a full government term in the office was <a href="/wiki/Scott_Morrison" title="Scott Morrison">Scott Morrison</a>, who won the 2019 election and led his party to the 2022 election, but was defeated and lost his title as prime minister.
</p><p>Lists of the 31 people who have so far held the premiership:
</p>
<ul><li><b><a href="/wiki/List_of_prime_ministers_of_Australia" title="List of prime ministers of Australia">List of prime ministers of Australia</a></b></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/List_of_prime_ministers_of_Australia_by_birthplace" title="List of prime ministers of Australia by birthplace">List of prime ministers of Australia by birthplace</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/List_of_prime_ministers_of_Australia_by_time_in_office" title="List of prime ministers of Australia by time in office">List of prime ministers of Australia by time in office</a></li></ul>

<li><a href="/wiki/Prime_Ministers%27_Corridor_of_Oaks" title="Prime Ministers&#39; Corridor of Oaks">Prime Ministers' Corridor of Oaks</a> in <a href="/wiki/Faulconbridge,_New_South_Wales" title="Faulconbridge, New South Wales">Faulconbridge, New South Wales</a> contains a corridor of oaks of former Australian prime ministers.</li>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Prime_Minister_of_Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: References"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Specific_references">Specific references</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Prime_Minister_of_Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Specific references"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>

<li id="cite_note-52"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-52">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1215172403"><cite id="CITEREFArklay2010" class="citation thesis cs1">Arklay, Tracey M. (2010). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20180528133311/https://www120.secure.griffith.edu.au/rch/file/9e60ec78-ebd2-d16e-3533-2af6f43a5cee/1/Arklay_2011_02Thesis.pdf"><i>Arthur Fadden: A Political Silhouette</i></a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> (PhD thesis). <a href="/wiki/Griffith_University" title="Griffith University">Griffith University</a>. p.&#160;196. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www120.secure.griffith.edu.au/rch/file/9e60ec78-ebd2-d16e-3533-2af6f43a5cee/1/Arklay_2011_02Thesis.pdf">the original</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> on 28 May 2018<span class="reference-accessdate">. Oxford University Press. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780199666423" title="Special:BookSources/9780199666423"><bdi>9780199666423</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Evaluating+Prime-Ministerial+Performance%3A+The+Australian+Experience&amp;rft.btitle=Understanding+Prime-Ministerial+Performance%3A+Comparative+Perspectives&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2013&amp;rft.isbn=9780199666423&amp;rft.aulast=Strangio&amp;rft.aufirst=Paul&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APrime+Minister+of+Australia" class="Z3988"></span></li>
<li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1215172403"><cite id="CITEREFStrangio&#39;t_HartWalter2016" class="citation book cs1">Strangio, Paul; 't Hart, Paul; Walter, James (2016). <i>Settling the Office: The Australian Prime Ministership from Federation to Reconstruction</i>. Melbourne University Press. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780522868722" title="Special:BookSources/9780522868722"><bdi>9780522868722</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Settling+the+Office%3A+The+Australian+Prime+Ministership+from+Federation+to+Reconstruction&amp;rft.pub=Melbourne+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft.isbn=9780522868722&amp;rft.aulast=Strangio&amp;rft.aufirst=Paul&amp;rft.au=%27t+Hart%2C+Paul&amp;rft.au=Walter%2C+James&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APrime+Minister+of+Australia" class="Z3988"></span></li>
<li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1215172403"><cite id="CITEREFStrangio&#39;t_HartWalter2017" class="citation book cs1">Strangio, Paul; 't Hart, Paul; Walter, James (2017). <i>The Pivot of Power: Australian Prime Ministers and Political Leadership, 1949-2016</i>. Melbourne University Press. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780522868746" title="Special:BookSources/9780522868746"><bdi>9780522868746</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Pivot+of+Power%3A+Australian+Prime+Ministers+and+Political+Leadership%2C+1949-2016&amp;rft.pub=Melbourne+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2017&amp;rft.isbn=9780522868746&amp;rft.aulast=Strangio&amp;rft.aufirst=Paul&amp;rft.au=%27t+Hart%2C+Paul&amp;rft.au=Walter%2C+James&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APrime+Minister+of+Australia" class="Z3988"></span></li>
<li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1215172403"><cite id="CITEREFWhitington1972" class="citation book cs1"><a href="/wiki/Don_Whitington" title="Don Whitington">Whitington, Don</a> (1972). <i>Twelfth Man?</i>. Jacaranda Press. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0701605855" title="Special:BookSources/0701605855"><bdi>0701605855</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Twelfth+Man%3F&amp;rft.pub=Jacaranda+Press&amp;rft.date=1972&amp;rft.isbn=0701605855&amp;rft.aulast=Whitington&amp;rft.aufirst=Don&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APrime+Minister+of+Australia" class="Z3988"></span></li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Prime_Minister_of_Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: External links"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1217611005">.mw-parser-output .side-box{margin:4px 0;box-sizing:border-box;border:1px solid #aaa;font-size:88%;line-height:1.25em;background-color:#f9f9f9;display:flow-root}.mw-parser-output .side-box-abovebelow,.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{padding:0.25em 0.9em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-image{padding:2px 0 2px 0.9em;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-imageright{padding:2px 0.9em 2px 0;text-align:center}@media(min-width:500px){.mw-parser-output .side-box-flex{display:flex;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{flex:1;min-width:0}}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .side-box{width:238px}.mw-parser-output .side-box-right{clear:right;float:right;margin-left:1em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-left{margin-right:1em}}</style><div class="side-box side-box-right plainlinks sistersitebox"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1126788409">
<div class="side-box-flex">
<div class="side-box-image"><span class="noviewer" typeof="mw:File"><span><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4a/Commons-logo.svg/30px-Commons-logo.svg.png" decoding="async" width="30" height="40" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4a/Commons-logo.svg/45px-Commons-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4a/Commons-logo.svg/59px-Commons-logo.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="1376" /></span></span></div>

					<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading mw-first-heading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Anthony Albanese</span></h1>
							
<div id="p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown mw-portlet mw-portlet-lang"  >
	<input type="checkbox" id="p-lang-btn-checkbox" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox mw-interlanguage-selector" aria-label="Go to an article in another language. Available in 65 languages"   >
	<label id="p-lang-btn-label" for="p-lang-btn-checkbox" class="vector-dropdown-label cdx-button cdx-button--fake-button cdx-button--fake-button--enabled cdx-button--weight-quiet cdx-button--action-progressive mw-portlet-lang-heading-65" aria-hidden="true"  ><span class="vector-icon mw-ui-icon-language-progressive mw-ui-icon-wikimedia-language-progressive"></span>

<span class="vector-dropdown-label-text">65 languages</span>
	</label>

					<div id="mw-content-text" class="mw-body-content"><div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" lang="en" dir="ltr"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Prime Minister of Australia since 2022</div>
