<p><b>Anthony Norman Albanese</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><small> </small><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˌ/: secondary stress follows">ˌ</span><span title="/æ/: &#39;a&#39; in &#39;bad&#39;">æ</span><span title="&#39;l&#39; in &#39;lie&#39;">l</span><span title="&#39;b&#39; in &#39;buy&#39;">b</span><span title="/ə/: &#39;a&#39; in &#39;about&#39;">ə</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="&#39;n&#39; in &#39;nigh&#39;">n</span><span title="/iː/: &#39;ee&#39; in &#39;fleece&#39;">iː</span><span title="&#39;z&#39; in &#39;zoom&#39;">z</span><span title="/i/: &#39;y&#39; in &#39;happy&#39;">i</span></span>/</a></span></span> <a href="/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key" title="Help:Pronunciation respelling key"><i title="English pronunciation respelling"><span style="font-size:90%">AL</span>-bə-<span style="font-size:90%">NEEZ</span>-ee</i></a> or <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><small> </small><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="/æ/: &#39;a&#39; in &#39;bad&#39;">æ</span><span title="&#39;l&#39; in &#39;lie&#39;">l</span><span title="&#39;b&#39; in &#39;buy&#39;">b</span><span title="/ə/: &#39;a&#39; in &#39;about&#39;">ə</span><span title="&#39;n&#39; in &#39;nigh&#39;">n</span><span title="/iː/: &#39;ee&#39; in &#39;fleece&#39;">iː</span><span title="&#39;z&#39; in &#39;zoom&#39;">z</span></span>/</a></span></span> <a href="/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key" title="Help:Pronunciation respelling key"><i title="English pronunciation respelling"><span style="font-size:90%">AL</span>-bə-neez</i></a>;<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;nb 1&#93;</a></sup> born 2 March 1963) is an Australian politician serving as the 31st and current <a href="/wiki/Prime_minister_of_Australia" class="mw-redirect" title="Prime minister of Australia">prime minister of Australia</a> since 2022.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> He has been leader of the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Labor_Party" title="Australian Labor Party">Australian Labor Party</a> (ALP) since 2019 and the <a href="/wiki/Member_of_parliament" title="Member of parliament">member of parliament</a> (MP) for the division of <a href="/wiki/Division_of_Grayndler" title="Division of Grayndler">Grayndler</a> since 1996. Albanese previously served as the 15th <a href="/wiki/Deputy_Prime_Minister_of_Australia" title="Deputy Prime Minister of Australia">deputy prime minister</a> under the <a href="/wiki/Rudd_government_(2013)" title="Rudd government (2013)">second Rudd government</a> in 2013. He held various <a href="/wiki/Minister_(government)" title="Minister (government)">ministerial positions</a> from 2007 to 2013 in the governments of <a href="/wiki/Kevin_Rudd" title="Kevin Rudd">Kevin Rudd</a> and <a href="/wiki/Julia_Gillard" title="Julia Gillard">Julia Gillard</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Albanese was born in <a href="/wiki/Sydney" title="Sydney">Sydney</a> to an Italian father and an <a href="/wiki/Irish-Australian" class="mw-redirect" title="Irish-Australian">Irish-Australian</a> mother, who raised him as a <a href="/wiki/Single_parent" title="Single parent">single parent</a>. Albanese attended <a href="/wiki/St_Mary%27s_Cathedral_College,_Sydney" title="St Mary&#39;s Cathedral College, Sydney">St Mary's Cathedral College</a> and studied economics at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Sydney" title="University of Sydney">University of Sydney</a>. As a student, he joined the Labor Party and later worked as a party official and research officer before entering Parliament.
</p><p>Albanese was elected to the <a href="/wiki/Australian_House_of_Representatives" title="Australian House of Representatives">House of Representatives</a> at the <a href="/wiki/1996_Australian_federal_election" title="1996 Australian federal election">1996 election</a>, winning the seat of Grayndler in <a href="/wiki/New_South_Wales" title="New South Wales">New South Wales</a>. He was first appointed to the <a href="/wiki/Shadow_cabinet_of_Australia" title="Shadow cabinet of Australia">shadow cabinet</a> in 2001 by <a href="/wiki/Simon_Crean" title="Simon Crean">Simon Crean</a> and went on to serve in a number of roles, eventually becoming <a href="/wiki/Manager_of_Opposition_Business_in_the_House_(Australia)" title="Manager of Opposition Business in the House (Australia)">Manager of Opposition Business</a> in 2006. After Labor's victory in the <a href="/wiki/2007_Australian_federal_election" title="2007 Australian federal election">2007 election</a>, Albanese was appointed <a href="/wiki/Leader_of_the_House_(Australia)" title="Leader of the House (Australia)">Leader of the House</a>, and was also made <a href="/wiki/Minister_for_Infrastructure,_Transport,_Regional_Development_and_Local_Government" title="Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government">Minister for Regional Development and Local Government</a> and <a href="/wiki/Minister_for_Infrastructure,_Transport,_Regional_Development_and_Local_Government" title="Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government">Minister for Infrastructure and Transport</a>. In the <a href="/wiki/2010_Australian_Labor_Party_leadership_spill" title="2010 Australian Labor Party leadership spill">subsequent leadership tensions</a> between Kevin Rudd and Julia Gillard from 2010 to 2013, Albanese was publicly critical of the conduct of both, calling for party unity. After supporting Rudd in the final <a href="/wiki/June_2013_Australian_Labor_Party_leadership_spill" title="June 2013 Australian Labor Party leadership spill">leadership ballot</a> between the two in June 2013, Albanese was elected the <a href="/wiki/Leaders_of_the_Australian_Labor_Party" title="Leaders of the Australian Labor Party">deputy leader of the Labor Party</a> and sworn in as deputy prime minister the following day, a position he held for less than three months, as Labor was defeated at the <a href="/wiki/2013_Australian_federal_election" title="2013 Australian federal election">2013 election</a>.
</p><p>Rudd retired from politics, so Albanese stood against <a href="/wiki/Bill_Shorten" title="Bill Shorten">Bill Shorten</a> in the <a href="/wiki/October_2013_Australian_Labor_Party_leadership_election" title="October 2013 Australian Labor Party leadership election">October 2013 Australian Labor Party leadership election</a>. Although Albanese won a large majority of the membership, Shorten won more heavily among Labor MPs and became leader. Shorten subsequently appointed Albanese to his Shadow Cabinet. After Labor's surprise defeat in the <a href="/wiki/2019_Australian_federal_election" title="2019 Australian federal election">2019 election</a>, Shorten resigned as leader, with Albanese becoming the only person nominated in the <a href="/wiki/2019_Australian_Labor_Party_leadership_election" title="2019 Australian Labor Party leadership election">leadership election to replace him</a>; he was subsequently elected unopposed as leader of the Labor Party, becoming <a href="/wiki/Leader_of_the_Opposition_(Australia)" title="Leader of the Opposition (Australia)">Leader of the Opposition</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/2022_Australian_federal_election" title="2022 Australian federal election">2022 election</a>, Albanese led his party to victory against <a href="/wiki/Scott_Morrison" title="Scott Morrison">Scott Morrison</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Liberal-National_Coalition" class="mw-redirect" title="Liberal-National Coalition">Liberal-National Coalition</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> He was sworn in on 23 May 2022.<sup id="cite_ref-swornin3_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-swornin3-12">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-swornin-abc_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-swornin-abc-13">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> Albanese's first acts as prime minister included <a href="/wiki/2023_Australian_Indigenous_Voice_referendum" title="2023 Australian Indigenous Voice referendum">proposing a change</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Australia" title="Constitution of Australia">Constitution</a> to include an <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_Voice_to_Parliament" title="Indigenous Voice to Parliament">Indigenous Voice to Parliament</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-abc.net.au_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-abc.net.au-15">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> updating Australia's climate targets in an effort to reach <a href="/wiki/Carbon_neutrality" class="mw-redirect" title="Carbon neutrality">carbon neutrality</a> by 2050, and supporting an increase to the national <a href="/wiki/Minimum_wage" title="Minimum wage">minimum wage</a>. His government legislated a <a href="/wiki/National_Anti-Corruption_Commission_(Australia)" title="National Anti-Corruption Commission (Australia)">national anti-corruption commission</a>, made major changes to <a href="/wiki/Australian_labour_law" title="Australian labour law">Australian labour law</a> and established the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Commission_into_the_Robodebt_Scheme" title="Royal Commission into the Robodebt Scheme">Royal Commission into the Robodebt Scheme</a>. In foreign policy, Albanese pledged further logistical support to Ukraine to assist with the <a href="/wiki/Russo-Ukrainian_war" class="mw-redirect" title="Russo-Ukrainian war">Russo-Ukrainian war</a>, attempted to strengthen relations in the Pacific region, and held several high-level discussions with Chinese president <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping" title="Xi Jinping">Xi Jinping</a>, overseeing an easing of tensions between the countries and leading to easing of trade restrictions put by China on Australia. He also oversaw the official commencement of the <a href="/wiki/AUKUS" title="AUKUS">AUKUS</a> security pact between Australia, the United States, and the United Kingdom.
</p>
<meta property="mw:PageProp/toc" />
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life">Early life</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Family_and_background">Family and background</span></h3>
<p>Albanese was born on 2 March 1963 at <a href="/wiki/St_Margaret%27s_Hospital,_Sydney" title="St Margaret&#39;s Hospital, Sydney">St Margaret's Hospital</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Sydney" title="Sydney">Sydney</a> suburb of <a href="/wiki/Darlinghurst,_New_South_Wales" class="mw-redirect" title="Darlinghurst, New South Wales">Darlinghurst</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-parlbio2_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-parlbio2-17">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiddleton201627_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiddleton201627-18">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup> He is the son of Carlo Albanese and Maryanne Ellery.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup> His mother was an Australian of Irish descent, while his Italian father was from <a href="/wiki/Barletta" title="Barletta">Barletta</a> in <a href="/wiki/Apulia" title="Apulia">Apulia</a>. His parents met in March 1962 on a voyage from Sydney to <a href="/wiki/Southampton" title="Southampton">Southampton</a>, <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">England</a>, on the <a href="/wiki/Sitmar_Cruises" title="Sitmar Cruises">Sitmar Line</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Fairsky" title="Fairsky">TSS <i>Fairsky</i></a>, where his father worked as a steward, but did not continue their relationship afterwards, going their separate ways.<sup id="cite_ref-middleton2_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-middleton2-20">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:02_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:02-21">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:12_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:12-22">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup> 
</p><p>Growing up, Albanese was told that his father had died in a car accident; he did not meet his father, who was in fact still alive, until 2009, tracking him down initially with the assistance of <a href="/wiki/John_Faulkner" title="John Faulkner">John Faulkner</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carnival_Corporation_%26_plc" title="Carnival Corporation &amp; plc">Carnival Australia's</a> CEO <a href="/wiki/Ann_Sherry" title="Ann Sherry">Ann Sherry</a> (the parent company of <a href="/wiki/P%26O_(company)" class="mw-redirect" title="P&amp;O (company)">P&amp;O</a>, which acquired the Sitmar Line in 1988) and maritime historian Rob Henderson, and then later the <a href="/wiki/List_of_ambassadors_of_Australia_to_Italy" title="List of ambassadors of Australia to Italy">Australian Embassy in Italy</a> and ambassador <a href="/wiki/Amanda_Vanstone" title="Amanda Vanstone">Amanda Vanstone</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-middleton2_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-middleton2-20">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> He made contact with his father in 2009, visiting him a number of times in Italy, and he took his family there as well. His father died in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup> He subsequently discovered that he had two half-siblings.<sup id="cite_ref-:02_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:02-21">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:12_22-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:12-22">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Australian_parliamentary_eligibility_crisis" class="mw-redirect" title="Australian parliamentary eligibility crisis">Australian parliamentary eligibility crisis</a> of 2017, it was noted that, although birth to an Italian father would ordinarily confer <a href="/wiki/Jus_sanguinis" title="Jus sanguinis">citizenship by descent</a>, Albanese had no father recorded on his birth certificate and thus meets the parliamentary eligibility requirements of <a href="/wiki/Section_44_of_the_Constitution_of_Australia" title="Section 44 of the Constitution of Australia">section 44 of the constitution</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Albanese's maternal grandfather George Ellery ran a printing business on <a href="/wiki/William_Street,_Sydney" title="William Street, Sydney">William Street</a> in Darlinghurst. He provided printing services to the ALP.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiddleton201629_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiddleton201629-25">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Childhood_and_education">Childhood and education</span></h3>
<p>Albanese grew up with his mother and maternal grandparents in a <a href="/wiki/Sydney_City_Council" class="mw-redirect" title="Sydney City Council">Sydney City Council</a> home in the <a href="/wiki/Inner_West" title="Inner West">Inner West</a> suburb of <a href="/wiki/Camperdown,_New_South_Wales" title="Camperdown, New South Wales">Camperdown</a>, opposite the <a href="/wiki/Camperdown_Children%27s_Hospital" class="mw-redirect" title="Camperdown Children&#39;s Hospital">Camperdown Children's Hospital</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiddleton201642_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiddleton201642-26">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup> His grandfather died in 1970, and the following year his mother married James Williamson. He was given his stepfather's surname, but the marriage lasted only 10 weeks, as Williamson proved to be an abusive alcoholic.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiddleton201636-38_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiddleton201636-38-27">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup> Albanese's mother worked part-time as a cleaner but suffered from chronic <a href="/wiki/Rheumatoid_arthritis" title="Rheumatoid arthritis">rheumatoid arthritis</a>, with the family surviving on her disability pension and his grandmother's age pension.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiddleton201638_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiddleton201638-28">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Albanese attended St Joseph's Primary School in Camperdown<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiddleton201644_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiddleton201644-29">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup> and then <a href="/wiki/St_Mary%27s_Cathedral_College,_Sydney" title="St Mary&#39;s Cathedral College, Sydney">St Mary's Cathedral College</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ALP_website_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ALP_website-30">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup> After finishing school, he worked for the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank" title="Commonwealth Bank">Commonwealth Bank</a> for two years before studying economics at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Sydney" title="University of Sydney">University of Sydney</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-parlbio2_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-parlbio2-17">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> There, he became involved in student politics and was elected to the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Sydney_Students%27_Representative_Council" title="University of Sydney Students&#39; Representative Council">Students' Representative Council</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-student_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-student-33">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup> It was also there where he started his rise as a key player in the ALP's <a href="/wiki/Labor_Left" title="Labor Left">Labor Left</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-crikey_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-crikey-34">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup> During his time in student politics, Albanese led a group within Young Labor that was aligned with the left faction's Hard Left, which maintained "links with broader left-wing groups, such as the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Australia_(1971)" title="Communist Party of Australia (1971)">Communist Party of Australia</a>, People for Nuclear Disarmament and the <a href="/wiki/African_National_Congress" title="African National Congress">African National Congress</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-factions&amp;fractions_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-factions&amp;fractions-35">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Albanese's mother died in 2002.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pre-parliamentary_career_and_travel">Pre-parliamentary career and travel</span></h3>
<p>After completing his economics degree in 1984,<sup id="cite_ref-cityhub_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cityhub-37">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup> Albanese took on a role as a research officer to the then <a href="/wiki/Minister_for_Local_Government,_Territories_and_Roads" class="mw-redirect" title="Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads">Minister for Local Government and</a> <a href="/wiki/Minister_for_Finance_(Australia)" title="Minister for Finance (Australia)">Administrative Services</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tom_Uren" title="Tom Uren">Tom Uren</a>, who became a mentor to him.<sup id="cite_ref-powerindex_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-powerindex-38">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup> In 1989, the position of Assistant General Secretary of the New South Wales branch of the Labor Party became vacant when <a href="/wiki/John_Faulkner" title="John Faulkner">John Faulkner</a> was elected to the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Senate" title="Australian Senate">Senate</a>. The election to replace him was closely disputed between the Labor Left's Hard Left and Soft Left groupings, with Albanese being elected with the backing of the Hard Left, taking on that role for the next six years.<sup id="cite_ref-factions&amp;fractions_35-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-factions&amp;fractions-35">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup> In 1995, he left the position to work as a senior adviser to <a href="/wiki/Premier_of_New_South_Wales" title="Premier of New South Wales">New South Wales Premier</a> <a href="/wiki/Bob_Carr" title="Bob Carr">Bob Carr</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-parlbio2_17-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-parlbio2-17">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Albanese's first overseas trip was in 1986, accompanying his friend <a href="/wiki/Jeremy_Fisher_(author)" title="Jeremy Fisher (author)">Jeremy Fisher</a> to <a href="/wiki/Vanuatu" title="Vanuatu">Vanuatu</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiddleton2016139_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiddleton2016139-39">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup> In 1987, Albanese joined his boss Tom Uren on a visit to South-East Asia, which included: a meeting of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Economic_and_Social_Commission_for_Asia_and_the_Pacific" title="United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific">United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific</a> in <a href="/wiki/Bangkok" title="Bangkok">Bangkok</a>, Thailand; an <a href="/wiki/Dawn_service" class="mw-redirect" title="Dawn service">Anzac Day dawn service</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Kanchanaburi_War_Cemetery" title="Kanchanaburi War Cemetery">Kanchanaburi War Cemetery</a> with <a href="/wiki/John_Carrick_(Australian_politician)" title="John Carrick (Australian politician)">John Carrick</a>; and a tour of <a href="/wiki/Cambodia" title="Cambodia">Cambodia</a> alongside <a href="/wiki/Bill_Hayden" title="Bill Hayden">Bill Hayden</a>'s daughter Ingrid.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiddleton2016140-43_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiddleton2016140-43-40">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup> He then travelled extensively in 1988, visiting <a href="/wiki/Zimbabwe" title="Zimbabwe">Zimbabwe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zambia" title="Zambia">Zambia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Botswana" title="Botswana">Botswana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">Western Europe</a> on a <a href="/wiki/Contiki_Tours" title="Contiki Tours">Contiki tour</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern Europe</a> and <a href="/wiki/Scandinavia" title="Scandinavia">Scandinavia</a> as a <a href="/wiki/Backpacking_(travel)" title="Backpacking (travel)">backpacker</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiddleton2016181-84_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiddleton2016181-84-41">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup> Upon returning to Australia, he began dating <a href="/wiki/Carmel_Tebbutt" title="Carmel Tebbutt">Carmel Tebbutt</a>, with whom he would holiday in Europe and South-East Asia,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiddleton2016191_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiddleton2016191-42">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup> plus a backpacking trip to <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> in 1991.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup> Sometime during his 20s, Albanese also took part in a tour of the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> organised by the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_State" title="United States Department of State">State Department</a>, with a thematic focus on the interaction of <a href="/wiki/Advocacy_group" title="Advocacy group">advocacy groups</a> with the U.S. Government.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1990, Albanese bought a <a href="/wiki/Semi-detached" title="Semi-detached">semi-detached</a> two-bedroom house in the Inner West Sydney suburb of <a href="/wiki/Marrickville,_New_South_Wales" title="Marrickville, New South Wales">Marrickville</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cityhub_37-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cityhub-37">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_political_career">Early political career</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Entry_to_Parliament">Entry to Parliament</span></h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Anthony_Albanese_1990s.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Anthony_Albanese_1990s.jpg/170px-Anthony_Albanese_1990s.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="213" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/82/Anthony_Albanese_1990s.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="200" data-file-height="250" /></a><figcaption>Albanese shortly after his election to Parliament</figcaption></figure>
<p>When <a href="/wiki/Jeannette_McHugh" title="Jeannette McHugh">Jeannette McHugh</a> announced she would not seek re-election in her seat of <a href="/wiki/Division_of_Grayndler" title="Division of Grayndler">Grayndler</a> at the <a href="/wiki/1996_Australian_federal_election" title="1996 Australian federal election">1996 election</a>, Albanese won preselection for the seat. The campaign was a difficult one, with aircraft noise a big political issue following the opening of the third runway at <a href="/wiki/Sydney_Airport" title="Sydney Airport">Sydney Airport</a>, and the newly established <a href="/wiki/No_Aircraft_Noise" title="No Aircraft Noise">No Aircraft Noise</a> party (NAN) having polled strongly in the local area at the <a href="/wiki/1995_New_South_Wales_state_election" title="1995 New South Wales state election">1995 New South Wales election</a>. Veteran political pundit <a href="/wiki/Malcolm_Mackerras" title="Malcolm Mackerras">Malcolm Mackerras</a> predicted NAN would win the seat. However, NAN's candidate finished third, with less than 14% of the vote. Despite suffering a six-point swing against Labor, Albanese was elected with a comfortable 16-point margin.<sup id="cite_ref-maiden_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-maiden-47">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In his maiden speech to the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Representatives_(Australia)" class="mw-redirect" title="House of Representatives (Australia)">House of Representatives</a>, he spoke about the building of a third runway at <a href="/wiki/Sydney_Airport" title="Sydney Airport">Sydney Airport</a>, aircraft noise and the need to build a second airport to service Sydney, as well as his support for funding public infrastructure in general, <a href="/wiki/Multiculturalism" title="Multiculturalism">multiculturalism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Native_title" class="mw-redirect" title="Native title">native title</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Social_wage" class="mw-redirect" title="Social wage">social wage</a> and childcare. He concluded by saying, "For myself, I will be satisfied if I can be remembered as someone who will stand up for the interests of my electorate, for working-class people, for the labour movement, and for our progressive advancement as a nation into the next century."<sup id="cite_ref-maiden_47-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-maiden-47">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In his first year in Parliament he continued this theme, speaking in favour of the <a href="/wiki/Rights_of_the_Terminally_Ill_Act_1995" title="Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995">Northern Territory's euthanasia legislation</a>, the rights of the Indigenous community in the <a href="/wiki/Hindmarsh_Island_bridge_controversy" title="Hindmarsh Island bridge controversy">Hindmarsh Island bridge controversy</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup> and entitlement to <a href="/wiki/Superannuation_in_Australia" title="Superannuation in Australia">superannuation</a> for same-sex couples.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>This latter issue became a cause to which he was particularly dedicated. In 1998 he unsuccessfully moved a private member's bill that would have given same-sex couples the same rights to superannuation as de facto heterosexual couples.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">&#91;50&#93;</a></sup> Over the next nine years, he tried three more times without success, until the election of the Rudd government in 2007 saw the legislation passed.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup> Albanese subsequently turned his attention to campaigning for same-sex marriage.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Appointment_to_Shadow_Cabinet">Appointment to Shadow Cabinet</span></h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Anthony_Albanese,_Australian_Labor_MP_in_2005.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Anthony_Albanese%2C_Australian_Labor_MP_in_2005.jpg/220px-Anthony_Albanese%2C_Australian_Labor_MP_in_2005.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="293" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/cc/Anthony_Albanese%2C_Australian_Labor_MP_in_2005.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="288" data-file-height="384" /></a><figcaption>Albanese in 2005</figcaption></figure>
<p>In 1998, Albanese was appointed a parliamentary secretary, a position which assists ministers and shadow ministers and is often a stepping stone to a full ministerial position.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">&#91;53&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2001, Albanese was promoted to the opposition <a href="/wiki/Shadow_Cabinet" class="mw-redirect" title="Shadow Cabinet">Shadow Cabinet</a>, taking the portfolio of ageing and seniors. A 2002 reshuffle saw him become Shadow Minister for Employment Services and Training, and in 2004 he became Shadow Minister for Environment and Heritage.<sup id="cite_ref-parlbio2_17-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-parlbio2-17">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> It was during this latter role that then prime minister <a href="/wiki/John_Howard" title="John Howard">John Howard</a> and science minister <a href="/wiki/Brendan_Nelson" title="Brendan Nelson">Brendan Nelson</a> started raising the idea of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_in_Australia" title="Nuclear power in Australia">nuclear power for Australia</a>. Albanese campaigned strongly against them, as well as elements within his own party, arguing that "Nuclear energy doesn't add up economically, environmentally or socially, and after more than 50 years of debate, we still do not have an answer to nuclear proliferation or nuclear waste."<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2005, Albanese was given the additional role of Shadow Minister for Water alongside his existing responsibilities, and was also appointed Deputy Manager of Opposition Business in the House. In December 2006, when <a href="/wiki/Kevin_Rudd" title="Kevin Rudd">Kevin Rudd</a> first became Leader of the Labor Party, Albanese took over from <a href="/wiki/Julia_Gillard" title="Julia Gillard">Julia Gillard</a> as <a href="/wiki/Manager_of_Opposition_Business_in_the_House_(Australia)" title="Manager of Opposition Business in the House (Australia)">Manager of Opposition Business in the House</a>, a senior tactical role on the floor of the parliament, and was appointed Shadow Minister for Water and Infrastructure.<sup id="cite_ref-parlbio2_17-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-parlbio2-17">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Cabinet_minister">Cabinet minister</span></h2>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Anthony_Albanese.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Anthony_Albanese.jpg/220px-Anthony_Albanese.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="314" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Anthony_Albanese.jpg/330px-Anthony_Albanese.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Anthony_Albanese.jpg/440px-Anthony_Albanese.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2239" data-file-height="3193" /></a><figcaption>Albanese in 2011</figcaption></figure>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Rudd_government">Rudd government</span></h3>
<p>Following Labor's victory at the <a href="/wiki/2007_Australian_federal_election" title="2007 Australian federal election">2007 election</a>, Albanese's rise in standing within the party was evidenced by his appointment as <a href="/wiki/Minister_for_Infrastructure,_Transport,_Regional_Development_and_Local_Government" title="Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government">Minister for Infrastructure and Transport</a>, <a href="/wiki/Minister_for_Regional_Development,_Local_Government_and_Territories" title="Minister for Regional Development, Local Government and Territories">Minister for Regional Development and Local Government</a> and <a href="/wiki/Leader_of_the_House_(Australia)" title="Leader of the House (Australia)">Leader of the House of Representatives</a> in the <a href="/wiki/First_Rudd_Ministry" class="mw-redirect" title="First Rudd Ministry">Rudd ministry</a>. Rudd was sworn in alongside his colleagues on 3 December 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Labor Party had gone to the election criticising the previous government for ignoring "long-term nation building in favour of short-term political spending".<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup> One of Albanese's first moves as Minister for Infrastructure and Transport was the establishment of an independent statutory body, <a href="/wiki/Infrastructure_Australia" title="Infrastructure Australia">Infrastructure Australia</a>, to advise the Government on infrastructure priorities. Armed with advice from this independent body and his own persuasive skills in the Cabinet, he was able to argue for a doubling of the roads budget and a tenfold increase in rail investment.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">&#91;58&#93;</a></sup> The establishment of Infrastructure Australia was regarded by many as a success; projects delivered through the Infrastructure Australia process included Melbourne's <a href="/wiki/Regional_Rail_Link" class="mw-redirect" title="Regional Rail Link">Regional Rail Link</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Hunter_Expressway" title="Hunter Expressway">Hunter Expressway</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ipswich_Motorway" title="Ipswich Motorway">Ipswich Motorway</a>, the Gold Coast light rail system <a href="/wiki/G:link" title="G:link">G:link</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Redcliffe_Peninsula_railway_line" title="Redcliffe Peninsula railway line">Redcliffe Peninsula railway line</a>, the extension of the <a href="/wiki/Seaford_railway_line" class="mw-redirect" title="Seaford railway line">Noarlunga Centre railway line</a> to <a href="/wiki/Seaford,_South_Australia" title="Seaford, South Australia">Seaford, South Australia</a> and various projects along the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Motorway_(Sydney%E2%80%93Newcastle)" title="Pacific Motorway (Sydney–Newcastle)">Pacific Highway</a> in NSW and <a href="/wiki/Bruce_Highway" title="Bruce Highway">Bruce Highway</a> in Queensland.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Gillard_government">Gillard government</span></h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Anthony_Albanese_2013_(cropped).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Anthony_Albanese_2013_%28cropped%29.jpg/170px-Anthony_Albanese_2013_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="238" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Anthony_Albanese_2013_%28cropped%29.jpg/255px-Anthony_Albanese_2013_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Anthony_Albanese_2013_%28cropped%29.jpg/340px-Anthony_Albanese_2013_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="733" data-file-height="1026" /></a><figcaption>Albanese at the opening of the Holbrook Bypass in 2013</figcaption></figure>
<p>After <a href="/wiki/Julia_Gillard" title="Julia Gillard">Julia Gillard</a> replaced Rudd as prime minister following the <a href="/wiki/2010_Australian_Labor_Party_leadership_spill" title="2010 Australian Labor Party leadership spill">leadership spill</a> in June 2010 she retained Albanese in his roles.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup> Following the <a href="/wiki/2010_Australian_federal_election" title="2010 Australian federal election">2010 election</a>, which resulted in a <a href="/wiki/Hung_parliament" title="Hung parliament">hung parliament</a>, Albanese was a key player in negotiating the support of independent members <a href="/wiki/Tony_Windsor" title="Tony Windsor">Tony Windsor</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rob_Oakeshott" title="Rob Oakeshott">Rob Oakeshott</a> through his role of Leader of the House. Albanese was also responsible for managing legislation through the House in the first hung parliament since the 1940s.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2011, Albanese introduced two more major policy reforms. The first on urban planning drew on the work of Danish designer <a href="/wiki/Jan_Gehl" title="Jan Gehl">Jan Gehl</a> and set out plans for urban design with better transport links and safety.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup> The second, on shipping, was notable for gaining the approval of both the conservative Australian Shipowners Associations and the radical <a href="/wiki/Maritime_Union_of_Australia" title="Maritime Union of Australia">Maritime Union of Australia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">&#91;63&#93;</a></sup> However, he also attracted controversy when a convoy of trucks from North Queensland dubbed the "convoy of no confidence" descended on Canberra's Parliament House to protest against rising fuel costs and <a href="/wiki/Carbon_pricing" class="mw-redirect" title="Carbon pricing">carbon pricing</a>. During question time, Albanese labelled the protesters outside as "the convoy of no consequence". This caused outrage among supporters of the protest and a week later a public rally in support of the truckies was held outside Albanese's electorate office in <a href="/wiki/Marrickville,_New_South_Wales" title="Marrickville, New South Wales">Marrickville</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_South_Wales" title="New South Wales">New South Wales</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Face-off_part_II_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Face-off_part_II-65">&#91;64&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Following a series of poor polls, leadership instability descended again on the Labor government. Former prime minister Kevin Rudd resigned as <a href="/wiki/Minister_for_Foreign_Affairs_(Australia)" title="Minister for Foreign Affairs (Australia)">Minister for Foreign Affairs</a> in February 2012 to <a href="/wiki/2012_Australian_Labor_Party_leadership_spill" title="2012 Australian Labor Party leadership spill">unsuccessfully challenge</a> Julia Gillard for the leadership.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">&#91;65&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup> Shortly before the ballot, Albanese came out in support of Rudd, stating that he had always been unhappy with the manner of Rudd's removal.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup> He tearfully explained how he had offered his resignation as Leader of the House to the prime minister, but that she had refused to accept it, and called on Labor to cease leadership divisions and unify. In response to a question on his personal feelings around the leadership spill, he stated "I like fighting Tories. That's what I do."<sup id="cite_ref-ANN_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ANN-69">&#91;68&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">&#91;69&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Deputy_Prime_Minister_of_Australia">Deputy Prime Minister of Australia</span></h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Anthony_Albanese_swearing-in_2013.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Anthony_Albanese_swearing-in_2013.jpg/220px-Anthony_Albanese_swearing-in_2013.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Anthony_Albanese_swearing-in_2013.jpg/330px-Anthony_Albanese_swearing-in_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Anthony_Albanese_swearing-in_2013.jpg/440px-Anthony_Albanese_swearing-in_2013.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2362" data-file-height="1572" /></a><figcaption>Albanese sworn in as deputy prime minister by <a href="/wiki/Governor-General_of_Australia" title="Governor-General of Australia">Governor-General</a> <a href="/wiki/Quentin_Bryce" title="Quentin Bryce">Quentin Bryce</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>In June 2013, Rudd defeated Gillard in a final <a href="/wiki/June_2013_Australian_Labor_Party_leadership_spill" title="June 2013 Australian Labor Party leadership spill">leadership election</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup> That same ballot saw Albanese elected by the caucus as <a href="/wiki/Leaders_of_the_Australian_Labor_Party#ALP_federal_deputy_parliamentary_leaders" title="Leaders of the Australian Labor Party">Deputy Leader of the Labor Party</a>, and the following day Albanese was sworn in as <a href="/wiki/Deputy_Prime_Minister_of_Australia" title="Deputy Prime Minister of Australia">deputy prime minister</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup> He held this role until Labor's defeat at the <a href="/wiki/2013_Australian_federal_election" title="2013 Australian federal election">2013 election</a>, and was replaced by <a href="/wiki/Warren_Truss" title="Warren Truss">Warren Truss</a> on 18 September.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">&#91;73&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">&#91;74&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Return_to_Opposition">Return to Opposition</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2013_leadership_election">2013 leadership election</span></h3>
<p>Following the defeat of Labor at the <a href="/wiki/2013_Australian_federal_election" title="2013 Australian federal election">2013 election</a>, Albanese announced his candidacy to be <a href="/wiki/Australian_Labor_Party#ALP_federal_parliamentary_leaders" title="Australian Labor Party">Leader of the Labor Party</a>, standing against <a href="/wiki/Bill_Shorten" title="Bill Shorten">Bill Shorten</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">&#91;75&#93;</a></sup> Shorten was announced as the winner after a month-long contest that was the first to involve a combined vote of MPs and rank-and-file members. Although Albanese won comfortably among party members, Shorten held a greater lead among MPs, and was subsequently elected.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Shorten_Opposition">Shorten Opposition</span></h3>
<p>In October 2013, shortly after the leadership election, Shorten appointed Albanese Shadow Minister for Infrastructure and Transport and Shadow Minister for Tourism; he held these roles throughout Shorten's time as leader.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">&#91;77&#93;</a></sup> In September 2014, Albanese was given the additional role of Shadow Minister for Cities.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">&#91;78&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Leader_of_the_Opposition_.282019.E2.80.932022.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Leader_of_the_Opposition_(2019–2022)">Leader of the Opposition (2019–2022)</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1097763485">.mw-parser-output .ambox{border:1px solid #a2a9b1;border-left:10px solid #36c;background-color:#fbfbfb;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+style+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+link+.ambox{margin-top:-1px}html body.mediawiki .mw-parser-output .ambox.mbox-small-left{margin:4px 1em 4px .ambox-move{border-left:10px solid #9932cc}.mw-parser-output .ambox-protection{border-left:10px solid #a2a9b1}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-text{border:none;padding:0.25em .mbox-text-span{margin-left:23px!important}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .ambox{margin:0 10%}}</style><table class="box-Expand_section plainlinks metadata ambox mbox-small-left ambox-content" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="[icon]" class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This section <b>needs expansion</b>.
