<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Australian_Labor_Party_Leader_Anthony_Albanese_MP_(cropped_-_tight).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Australian_Labor_Party_Leader_Anthony_Albanese_MP_%28cropped_-_tight%29.jpg/170px-Australian_Labor_Party_Leader_Anthony_Albanese_MP_%28cropped_-_tight%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="255" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Australian_Labor_Party_Leader_Anthony_Albanese_MP_%28cropped_-_tight%29.jpg/255px-Australian_Labor_Party_Leader_Anthony_Albanese_MP_%28cropped_-_tight%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Australian_Labor_Party_Leader_Anthony_Albanese_MP_%28cropped_-_tight%29.jpg/340px-Australian_Labor_Party_Leader_Anthony_Albanese_MP_%28cropped_-_tight%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1089" data-file-height="1633" /></a><figcaption>Albanese during his time as Leader of the Opposition</figcaption></figure>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2019_leadership_election">2019 leadership election</span></h3>
<p>Bill Shorten announced his resignation as Leader of the Labor Party on 18 May 2019, following Labor's unexpected defeat in the <a href="/wiki/2019_Australian_federal_election" title="2019 Australian federal election">2019 election</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-bbc-48304993_80-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-48304993-80">&#91;79&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">&#91;80&#93;</a></sup> The day after, Albanese announced his candidacy in the subsequent <a href="/wiki/2019_Australian_Labor_Party_leadership_election" title="2019 Australian Labor Party leadership election">leadership election</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">&#91;81&#93;</a></sup> On 21 May, <a href="/wiki/Chris_Bowen" title="Chris Bowen">Chris Bowen</a> announced he would also contest the ballot; however, the next day, he announced his withdrawal, citing his lack of support among the party membership.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">&#91;82&#93;</a></sup> With no other candidate stepping forward, Albanese took the leadership unopposed on 30 May, with <a href="/wiki/Richard_Marles" title="Richard Marles">Richard Marles</a> as his deputy.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">&#91;83&#93;</a></sup> Aged 56 when he took office, he became the oldest first-time Opposition Leader in 59 years, since <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Calwell" title="Arthur Calwell">Arthur Calwell</a> (aged 63) took office in 1960.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">&#91;84&#93;</a></sup> Albanese unveiled his <a href="/wiki/Shadow_Ministry_of_Anthony_Albanese" title="Shadow Ministry of Anthony Albanese">shadow ministry</a> on 1 June 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">&#91;85&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2022_federal_election">2022 federal election</span></h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Secretary_Blinken_Meets_With_Australian_Opposition_Party_Leadership_(51873384262).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="Albanese, Penny Wong and Antony Blinken posing for a photo, wearing black facemasks and standing in front of the US and Australian flags." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Secretary_Blinken_Meets_With_Australian_Opposition_Party_Leadership_%2851873384262%29.jpg/220px-Secretary_Blinken_Meets_With_Australian_Opposition_Party_Leadership_%2851873384262%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Secretary_Blinken_Meets_With_Australian_Opposition_Party_Leadership_%2851873384262%29.jpg/330px-Secretary_Blinken_Meets_With_Australian_Opposition_Party_Leadership_%2851873384262%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Secretary_Blinken_Meets_With_Australian_Opposition_Party_Leadership_%2851873384262%29.jpg/440px-Secretary_Blinken_Meets_With_Australian_Opposition_Party_Leadership_%2851873384262%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="7568" data-file-height="5045" /></a><figcaption>Albanese and Penny Wong (right) meeting with Antony Blinken (centre) in February 2022</figcaption></figure>
<p>Albanese led the Labor Party into the <a href="/wiki/2022_Australian_federal_election" title="2022 Australian federal election">2022 federal election</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup> On the first day of campaigning, Albanese was unable to name either the <a href="/wiki/Official_cash_rate" title="Official cash rate">official cash rate</a> or unemployment rate, which drew criticism.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">&#91;87&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">&#91;88&#93;</a></sup> On 20 April, Albanese faced prime minister <a href="/wiki/Scott_Morrison" title="Scott Morrison">Scott Morrison</a> in a debate hosted by <a href="/wiki/Sky_News_Australia" title="Sky News Australia">Sky News</a>, with Albanese being deemed the winner through an audience vote.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">&#91;89&#93;</a></sup> However, the next day, Albanese tested positive for <a href="/wiki/COVID-19" title="COVID-19">COVID-19</a>, forcing him to isolate at home in Sydney.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">&#91;90&#93;</a></sup> He returned to campaigning the following week and, on 1 May, hosted Labor's campaign launch in Perth which was the first time any major party launched in Western Australia. At the launch, Labor unveiled policies to reduce the cost of medicine and childcare, increase <a href="/wiki/Manufacturing_in_Australia" title="Manufacturing in Australia">manufacturing in Australia</a>, and introduce a <a href="/wiki/Equity_sharing" title="Equity sharing">shared equity housing scheme</a> to assist first-time home buyers.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">&#91;91&#93;</a></sup> Albanese faced Morrison in two further debates, hosted by <a href="/wiki/Nine_Network" title="Nine Network">Channel Nine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Seven_Network" title="Seven Network">Channel Seven</a>, respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">&#91;92&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">&#91;94&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">&#91;95&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Opinion_polls" class="mw-redirect" title="Opinion polls">Opinion polling</a> indicated that support for the two major parties had reached record lows, due to high levels of support for minor parties and independent candidates.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">&#91;96&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">&#91;97&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">&#91;98&#93;</a></sup> However, unlike his predecessor, Albanese was able to ultimately able to lead the Labor Party to federal victory, defeating Prime Minister Scott Morrison and his government with a one-seat majority in the House of Representatives.
</p>
<h2><span id="Prime_Minister_of_Australia_.282022.E2.80.93present.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Prime_Minister_of_Australia_(2022–present)">Prime Minister of Australia (2022–present)</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Albanese_government" title="Albanese government">Albanese government</a> and <a href="/wiki/Albanese_ministry" title="Albanese ministry">Albanese ministry</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1097763485"><table class="box-Update plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Update" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div class="mbox-image-div"><span typeof="mw:File"><span><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg/42px-Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg.png" decoding="async" width="42" height="34" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg/63px-Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg/84px-Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="360" data-file-height="290" /></span></span></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article needs to be <b>updated</b>. The reason given is: Missing information on 2023 budget.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help update this article to reflect recent events or newly available information.</span>  <span class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">May 2023</span>)</i></span></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:V%C3%B5_V%C4%83n_Th%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Fng_and_Anthony_Albanese.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/V%C3%B5_V%C4%83n_Th%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Fng_and_Anthony_Albanese.jpg/250px-V%C3%B5_V%C4%83n_Th%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Fng_and_Anthony_Albanese.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="154" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/V%C3%B5_V%C4%83n_Th%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Fng_and_Anthony_Albanese.jpg/375px-V%C3%B5_V%C4%83n_Th%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Fng_and_Anthony_Albanese.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/V%C3%B5_V%C4%83n_Th%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Fng_and_Anthony_Albanese.jpg/500px-V%C3%B5_V%C4%83n_Th%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Fng_and_Anthony_Albanese.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1063" data-file-height="653" /></a><figcaption>Albanese with Vietnamese President <a href="/wiki/V%C3%B5_V%C4%83n_Th%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Fng" title="Võ Văn Thưởng">Võ Văn Thưởng</a> in Hanoi, Vietnam, June 2023</figcaption></figure>
<p>Labor was victorious over the incumbent <a href="/wiki/Coalition_(Australia)" title="Coalition (Australia)">Liberal-National Coalition</a> at the federal election on 21 May 2022, with Albanese becoming the 31st prime minister of Australia.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">&#91;99&#93;</a></sup> Despite a fall in the party's primary vote, Labor won a number of seats from the Coalition, helped by a particularly large swing to the party in <a href="/wiki/Western_Australia" title="Western Australia">Western Australia</a>; the result was also assisted by a number of "<a href="/wiki/Teal_independents" title="Teal independents">teal independents</a>" winning seats from <a href="/wiki/Moderates_(Liberal_Party_of_Australia)" title="Moderates (Liberal Party of Australia)">"moderate" Liberal members</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">&#91;100&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">&#91;101&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Although it was not certain that Labor would win a majority, it soon became apparent that no other party could realistically form a government.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">&#91;102&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">&#91;103&#93;</a></sup> Accordingly, two days after the election, Albanese, deputy Labor leader <a href="/wiki/Richard_Marles" title="Richard Marles">Richard Marles</a>, shadow treasurer <a href="/wiki/Jim_Chalmers" title="Jim Chalmers">Jim Chalmers</a>, and shadow ministers for Foreign Affairs and Finance Senators <a href="/wiki/Penny_Wong" title="Penny Wong">Penny Wong</a> and <a href="/wiki/Katy_Gallagher" title="Katy Gallagher">Katy Gallagher</a> were sworn in as an interim five-person ministry. According to Australia's <a href="/wiki/ABC_News_(Australia)" title="ABC News (Australia)">ABC News</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Governor-General_of_Australia" title="Governor-General of Australia">Governor-General</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Hurley" title="David Hurley">David Hurley</a>, would not have sworn in Albanese without assurances that Labor could provide stable government, as well as legal advice that this was the proper course of action.<sup id="cite_ref-swornin-abc_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-swornin-abc-13">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> Albanese is the first <a href="/wiki/Italian-Australian" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian-Australian">Italian-Australian</a> prime minister in the country's history.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">&#91;104&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Albanese secured <a href="/wiki/Confidence_and_supply" title="Confidence and supply">confidence and supply</a> from several <a href="/wiki/Crossbencher" title="Crossbencher">crossbenchers</a> in the event that he was unable to form <a href="/wiki/Majority_government" title="Majority government">majority government</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">&#91;105&#93;</a></sup> However, on 30 May, it was projected that Labor had won at least 76 seats, enough to win a majority for the first time at the federal level since the <a href="/wiki/2007_Australian_federal_election" title="2007 Australian federal election">2007 election</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">&#91;106&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">&#91;107&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Albanese_ministry" title="Albanese ministry">Albanese's full ministry</a> was sworn in on 1 June.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">&#91;108&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Domestic_affairs">Domestic affairs</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Environment_and_climate_change">Environment and climate change</span></h4>
<p>On 16 June 2022, Albanese submitted a new <a href="/wiki/Nationally_determined_contribution" title="Nationally determined contribution">Nationally Determined Contribution</a> to the United Nations which formally committed Australia to reducing <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas_emissions_by_Australia" title="Greenhouse gas emissions by Australia">carbon emissions</a> by 43% on 2005 levels. This represented an increase from the 26 to 28% target under the previous government.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">&#91;109&#93;</a></sup> In September 2022, the Albanese government passed legislation to write this climate target into law.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">&#91;110&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">&#91;111&#93;</a></sup> Albanese's government also entered a bid for Australia and its Pacific island neighbours to host the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Climate_Change_conference" class="mw-redirect" title="United Nations Climate Change conference">2024 United Nations Climate Change conference</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In late-2022, his government announced reforms to the "safeguard mechanism", which requires Australia's largest carbon emitters to keep their emissions under a "baseline limit", either by reducing them, or by purchasing <a href="/wiki/Carbon_credit" class="mw-redirect" title="Carbon credit">carbon credits</a>. The mechanism was introduced by the <a href="/wiki/Turnbull_government" title="Turnbull government">Turnbull government</a> in 2016, but failed to reduce emissions as the rules were often left unenforced.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">&#91;113&#93;</a></sup> In March 2023, the Albanese government received the necessary support to pass the legislation from the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Greens" title="Australian Greens">Greens</a>, who negotiated a "hard cap" on emissions that cannot be offset by carbon credits.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">&#91;114&#93;</a></sup> The bill was passed on 30 March 2023, marking the most significant piece of climate change legislation passed through the Australian parliament since the <i><a href="/wiki/Clean_Energy_Act_2011" title="Clean Energy Act 2011">Clean Energy Act 2011</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">&#91;115&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In December 2023, the government legislated a "nature repair market" to create a <a href="/wiki/Economics_of_biodiversity" title="Economics of biodiversity">biodiversity market</a> to encourage private companies to invest in projects that <a href="/wiki/Conservation_in_Australia" title="Conservation in Australia">protect biodiversity</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup> and has committed to establishing a federal environmental protection agency.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Indigenous_affairs">Indigenous affairs</span></h4>
<p>In his victory speech, Albanese expressed his support for the <i><a href="/wiki/Uluru_Statement_from_the_Heart" title="Uluru Statement from the Heart">Uluru Statement from the Heart</a></i>, and stated that his government would implement it in full within its first term.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">&#91;118&#93;</a></sup> He pledged to hold a referendum to enshrine an <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_Voice_to_Parliament" title="Indigenous Voice to Parliament">Indigenous Voice to Parliament</a> to assist the government with Indigenous issues, and <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_recognition_of_Indigenous_Australians" title="Constitutional recognition of Indigenous Australians">recognise</a> Indigenous Australians in <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Australia" title="Constitution of Australia">Australia's constitution</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">&#91;119&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">&#91;120&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/2023_Australian_Indigenous_Voice_referendum" title="2023 Australian Indigenous Voice referendum">referendum</a> was held on 14 October 2023 and the change to the Constitution was rejected by the majority of Australian voters and passed in no state or territory, bar the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Capital_Territory" title="Australian Capital Territory">Australian Capital Territory</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">&#91;121&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-abc.net.au_15-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-abc.net.au-15">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Immigration_and_asylum">Immigration and asylum</span></h4>
<p>On 25 May 2022, in one of its first acts upon coming to government, the Albanese government allowed the <a href="/wiki/Murugappan_family_asylum_claims" title="Murugappan family asylum claims">Murugappan family</a> to stay in Australia after the previous Morrison government had attempted to deport them.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">&#91;122&#93;</a></sup> In February 2023, the Albanese government abolished <a href="/wiki/Temporary_protection_visa" title="Temporary protection visa">temporary protection visas</a>, allowing up to 19,000 asylum seekers to stay in Australia permanently.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">&#91;123&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">&#91;124&#93;</a></sup> On 8 November 2023, the <a href="/wiki/High_Court_of_Australia" title="High Court of Australia">High Court of Australia</a> ruled that <a href="/wiki/Indefinite_detention" title="Indefinite detention">indefinite detention</a> of immigrants was illegal, leading to the release of 148 people, some of whom had committed serious crimes.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">&#91;125&#93;</a></sup> In response, the government enacted emergency legislation to put those released under strict visa conditions − including mandating the use of ankle monitoring and a mandatory curfew – and establish a <a href="/wiki/Preventive_detention" title="Preventive detention">preventive detention</a> scheme to re-detain people who were found to pose a high risk to the community.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">&#91;126&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 11 December 2023, the Albanese government announced a overhaul of Australia's immigration system, with plans to cut the immigration intake in half to 250,000 by June 2025.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">&#91;127&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Housing">Housing</span></h4>
<p>On 13 September 2023, the government passed the Housing Australia Future Fund, a $10 billion fund designed to build 30,000 new social and affordable homes over the following five years.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">&#91;128&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Industrial_relations_and_employment">Industrial relations and employment</span></h4>
<p>In one of his first acts as prime minister on 27 May 2022, Albanese confirmed that his government would make a submission to the <a href="/wiki/Fair_Work_Commission" title="Fair Work Commission">Fair Work Commission</a> in support of an increase to the national minimum wage.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">&#91;129&#93;</a></sup> On 2 June 2023, the Albanese government contributed to a decision by the Fair Work Commission with another letter encouraging a rise in the minimum wage in line with inflation.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">&#91;130&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">&#91;131&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">&#91;132&#93;</a></sup> The government announced that a submission had been formally made to the commission on 3 June 2022 and that a "deliberate" policy of lower wages was not the policy of the new government.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">&#91;133&#93;</a></sup> The Fair Work Commission subsequently announced on 15 June 2022 that the minimum wage would be raised by 5.2%.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">&#91;134&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The government passed new workplace harassment laws through the Parliament on 28 November 2022. The news laws are in line with Albanese's promise to implement the recommendations of the Respect@Work Report by creating a positive duty requiring employers to implement measures to prevent sexual harassment.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">&#91;135&#93;</a></sup> On 2 December 2022, the government's <i>Secure Jobs, Better Pay</i> bill passed the Parliament. Under the new laws, unions can now negotiate multi-employer pay deals in an effort to secure wage increases across particular sectors such as child care and aged care. The law also aims to close the gender pay gap by prohibiting pay secrecy employment clauses and secures the right of workers to seek flexible working arrangements.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">&#91;136&#93;</a></sup> Throughout 2023, the Albanese government attempted to pass additional industrial relations reforms through Parliament, dubbed the <i>Closing Loopholes</i> bill, which aimed to ensure temporary workers employed through <a href="/wiki/Labour_hire_(Australia)" title="Labour hire (Australia)">labour hire</a> were paid the same wage as regular workers, criminalise <a href="/wiki/Wage_theft" title="Wage theft">wage theft</a> and make companies responsible for <a href="/wiki/Industrial_manslaughter" title="Industrial manslaughter">industrial manslaughter</a>, among other changes.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">&#91;137&#93;</a></sup> Despite fierce opposition from the Liberal Party and business lobbies, the first part of the bill was passed by the Senate on 7 December 2023.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">&#91;138&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">&#91;139&#93;</a></sup> The second tranche of legislation, which introduced minimum standards for <a href="/wiki/Gig_worker" title="Gig worker">gig workers</a> and allowed workers the <a href="/wiki/Right_to_disconnect" title="Right to disconnect">right to disconnect</a>, was passed on 8 February 2024.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">&#91;140&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_integrity_and_national_anti-corruption_commission">Government integrity and national anti-corruption commission</span></h4>
<p>In November 2022, Albanese's government fulfilled its election commitment to legislate the <a href="/wiki/National_Anti-Corruption_Commission_(Australia)" title="National Anti-Corruption Commission (Australia)">National Anti-Corruption Commission</a> (NACC), with the commission commencing on 1 July 2023.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">&#91;141&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">&#91;142&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">&#91;143&#93;</a></sup> Following the revelation that former prime minister Scott Morrison had <a href="/wiki/Scott_Morrison_ministerial_positions_controversy" title="Scott Morrison ministerial positions controversy">secretly sworn himself into several ministerial positions</a>, Albanese and his government successfully moved a <a href="/wiki/Censure" title="Censure">censure</a> motion against him in November 2022.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">&#91;144&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy_and_taxation">Economy and taxation</span></h4>
<p>In the <a href="/wiki/2023_Australian_federal_budget" title="2023 Australian federal budget">2023 Australian federal budget</a>, the Albanese government delivered a surplus of $22.1 billion (equivalent to 0.9% of Australia’s GDP); this is Australia's first budget surplus in 15 years, and the largest ever Australian budget surplus.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">&#91;145&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">&#91;146&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">&#91;147&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">&#91;148&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">&#91;149&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">&#91;150&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In January 2024, the Albanese government made changes to the previously legislated <a href="/wiki/Stage_three_tax_cuts" title="Stage three tax cuts">stage three tax cuts</a>, which would see individuals earning less than A$150,000 receive a larger tax cut than under the original plan.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">&#91;151&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">&#91;152&#93;</a></sup> These changes were met with some criticism, particularly by the Opposition and conservative media outlets, and was viewed as a breach of a pre-election promise, as Albanese had repeatedly stated he would not alter the tax cuts if elected.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">&#91;153&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">&#91;154&#93;</a></sup> Despite this, the changes proved popular with the public,<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">&#91;155&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">&#91;156&#93;</a></sup> and the overhauled tax cuts were passed by the Senate on 27 February 2024.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">&#91;157&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="International_affairs">International affairs</span></h3>
<figure class="mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Prime_Minister,_Shri_Narendra_Modi_at_the_QUAD_Leaders%E2%80%99_Family_Photo,_in_Tokyo,_Japan_on_May_24,_2022.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/The_Prime_Minister%2C_Shri_Narendra_Modi_at_the_QUAD_Leaders%E2%80%99_Family_Photo%2C_in_Tokyo%2C_Japan_on_May_24%2C_2022.jpg/241px-The_Prime_Minister%2C_Shri_Narendra_Modi_at_the_QUAD_Leaders%E2%80%99_Family_Photo%2C_in_Tokyo%2C_Japan_on_May_24%2C_2022.jpg" decoding="async" width="241" height="178" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/The_Prime_Minister%2C_Shri_Narendra_Modi_at_the_QUAD_Leaders%E2%80%99_Family_Photo%2C_in_Tokyo%2C_Japan_on_May_24%2C_2022.jpg/362px-The_Prime_Minister%2C_Shri_Narendra_Modi_at_the_QUAD_Leaders%E2%80%99_Family_Photo%2C_in_Tokyo%2C_Japan_on_May_24%2C_2022.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/The_Prime_Minister%2C_Shri_Narendra_Modi_at_the_QUAD_Leaders%E2%80%99_Family_Photo%2C_in_Tokyo%2C_Japan_on_May_24%2C_2022.jpg/482px-The_Prime_Minister%2C_Shri_Narendra_Modi_at_the_QUAD_Leaders%E2%80%99_Family_Photo%2C_in_Tokyo%2C_Japan_on_May_24%2C_2022.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2200" data-file-height="1622" /></a><figcaption>On the same day he was sworn in as prime minister, Albanese attended his first overseas trip: the <a href="/wiki/Quadrilateral_Security_Dialogue" title="Quadrilateral Security Dialogue">Quadrilateral Security Dialogue</a> meeting with US president <a href="/wiki/Joe_Biden" title="Joe Biden">Joe Biden</a>, Indian prime minister <a href="/wiki/Narendra_Modi" title="Narendra Modi">Narendra Modi</a> and Japanese prime minister <a href="/wiki/Fumio_Kishida" title="Fumio Kishida">Fumio Kishida</a></figcaption></figure>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_international_prime_ministerial_trips_made_by_Anthony_Albanese" title="List of international prime ministerial trips made by Anthony Albanese">List of international prime ministerial trips made by Anthony Albanese</a></div>
<p>Albanese took his first international trip on 23 May 2022 immediately after being sworn in as prime minister when he flew to Tokyo to attend a <a href="/wiki/Quadrilateral_Security_Dialogue" title="Quadrilateral Security Dialogue">Quadrilateral Security Dialogue</a> meeting with fellow world leaders: US president <a href="/wiki/Joe_Biden" title="Joe Biden">Joe Biden</a>, Indian prime minister <a href="/wiki/Narendra_Modi" title="Narendra Modi">Narendra Modi</a> and Japanese prime minister <a href="/wiki/Fumio_Kishida" title="Fumio Kishida">Fumio Kishida</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">&#91;158&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">&#91;159&#93;</a></sup> At the meeting, Albanese committed his new government to the goals of the Quad and confirmed that his government would seek to take stronger action in reducing carbon emissions.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">&#91;160&#93;</a></sup> On 5 June, Albanese and <a href="/wiki/Penny_Wong" title="Penny Wong">Penny Wong</a> visited Indonesian president <a href="/wiki/Joko_Widodo" title="Joko Widodo">Joko Widodo</a> in <a href="/wiki/Jakarta" title="Jakarta">Jakarta</a> to develop <a href="/wiki/Australia%E2%80%93Indonesia_relations" title="Australia–Indonesia relations">Australia–Indonesia relations</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">&#91;161&#93;</a></sup> Albanese said he would not "publicly intervene" to prevent <a href="/wiki/WikiLeaks" title="WikiLeaks">WikiLeaks</a> founder <a href="/wiki/Julian_Assange" title="Julian Assange">Julian Assange</a> from being extradited to the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">&#91;162&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%97%D1%83%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D1%96%D1%87_%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B0_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%B8_%D0%B7_%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BC%27%D1%94%D1%80-%D0%BC%D1%96%D0%BD%D1%96%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%90%D0%B2%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%96%D1%97_09.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/%D0%97%D1%83%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D1%96%D1%87_%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B0_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%B8_%D0%B7_%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BC%27%D1%94%D1%80-%D0%BC%D1%96%D0%BD%D1%96%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%90%D0%B2%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%96%D1%97_09.jpg/220px-%D0%97%D1%83%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D1%96%D1%87_%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B0_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%B8_%D0%B7_%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BC%27%D1%94%D1%80-%D0%BC%D1%96%D0%BD%D1%96%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%90%D0%B2%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%96%D1%97_09.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/%D0%97%D1%83%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D1%96%D1%87_%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B0_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%B8_%D0%B7_%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BC%27%D1%94%D1%80-%D0%BC%D1%96%D0%BD%D1%96%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%90%D0%B2%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%96%D1%97_09.jpg/330px-%D0%97%D1%83%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D1%96%D1%87_%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B0_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%B8_%D0%B7_%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BC%27%D1%94%D1%80-%D0%BC%D1%96%D0%BD%D1%96%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%90%D0%B2%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%96%D1%97_09.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/%D0%97%D1%83%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D1%96%D1%87_%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B0_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%B8_%D0%B7_%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BC%27%D1%94%D1%80-%D0%BC%D1%96%D0%BD%D1%96%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%90%D0%B2%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%96%D1%97_09.jpg/440px-%D0%97%D1%83%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D1%96%D1%87_%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B0_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%B8_%D0%B7_%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BC%27%D1%94%D1%80-%D0%BC%D1%96%D0%BD%D1%96%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%90%D0%B2%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%96%D1%97_09.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="2001" /></a><figcaption>Albanese visiting Ukrainian president <a href="/wiki/Volodymyr_Zelenskyy" title="Volodymyr Zelenskyy">Volodymyr Zelenskyy</a> in Kyiv</figcaption></figure>
<p>Later in June, Albanese attended the <a href="/wiki/2022_NATO_Madrid_summit" class="mw-redirect" title="2022 NATO Madrid summit">2022 NATO Madrid summit</a> to discuss security threats facing the Pacific region.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">&#91;163&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">&#91;164&#93;</a></sup> On 30 June, Albanese met with French president <a href="/wiki/Emmanuel_Macron" title="Emmanuel Macron">Emmanuel Macron</a> in Paris to "reset" <a href="/wiki/Australia%E2%80%93France_relations" title="Australia–France relations">Australia–France relations</a>, which had been damaged following the cancellation of a <a href="/wiki/Attack-class_submarine" title="Attack-class submarine">submarine deal</a> by the preceding government.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">&#91;165&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">&#91;166&#93;</a></sup> The next day, Albanese travelled to Ukraine to meet with President <a href="/wiki/Volodymyr_Zelenskyy" title="Volodymyr Zelenskyy">Volodymyr Zelenskyy</a>, making him the first Australian prime minister to make a diplomatic visit to Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">&#91;167&#93;</a></sup> Albanese pledged a further $100 million in aid to assist with the ongoing <a href="/wiki/Russo-Ukrainian_War" title="Russo-Ukrainian War">Russo-Ukrainian War</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">&#91;168&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 26 September 2022, Albanese travelled to Japan to attend the state funeral of former prime minister <a href="/wiki/Shinzo_Abe" title="Shinzo Abe">Shinzo Abe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">&#91;169&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:President_Joe_Biden,_British_Prime_Minister_Rishi_Sunak_and_Australian_Prime_Minister_Anthony_Albanese_at_the_AUKUS_meeting_in_San_Diego,_California,_March_13,_2023_-_230313-D-TT977-0319.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/President_Joe_Biden%2C_British_Prime_Minister_Rishi_Sunak_and_Australian_Prime_Minister_Anthony_Albanese_at_the_AUKUS_meeting_in_San_Diego%2C_California%2C_March_13%2C_2023_-_230313-D-TT977-0319.jpg/220px-thumbnail.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/President_Joe_Biden%2C_British_Prime_Minister_Rishi_Sunak_and_Australian_Prime_Minister_Anthony_Albanese_at_the_AUKUS_meeting_in_San_Diego%2C_California%2C_March_13%2C_2023_-_230313-D-TT977-0319.jpg/330px-thumbnail.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/President_Joe_Biden%2C_British_Prime_Minister_Rishi_Sunak_and_Australian_Prime_Minister_Anthony_Albanese_at_the_AUKUS_meeting_in_San_Diego%2C_California%2C_March_13%2C_2023_-_230313-D-TT977-0319.jpg/440px-thumbnail.jpg 2x" data-file-width="7047" data-file-height="4698" /></a><figcaption>Albanese (far left) at an <a href="/wiki/AUKUS" title="AUKUS">AUKUS</a> summit in March 2023</figcaption></figure>
<p>The relationship between Australia and China started to improve since Albanese became prime minister.<sup id="cite_ref-:2_171-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-171">&#91;170&#93;</a></sup> In November 2022, Albanese held a bilateral meeting with Chinese President <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping" title="Xi Jinping">Xi Jinping</a>, bringing an end to the longest diplomatic freeze in 50 years between Australia and China.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">&#91;171&#93;</a></sup> In early 2023, China ended its unofficial ban on imports of Australian coal,<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">&#91;172&#93;</a></sup> with all restrictions reportedly being lifted by 14 March.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">&#91;173&#93;</a></sup> China agreed to lift its ban on barley imports from Australia in April,<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">&#91;174&#93;</a></sup> and imports of Australian timber in May, further improving the relations.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">&#91;175&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In February 2023, Albanese hosted his <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_New_Zealand" title="Prime Minister of New Zealand">New Zealand counterpart</a> <a href="/wiki/Chris_Hipkins" title="Chris Hipkins">Chris Hipkins</a>, who undertook his first official visit. While the two leaders reaffirmed <a href="/wiki/Australia-New_Zealand_relations" class="mw-redirect" title="Australia-New Zealand relations">Australian-New Zealand bilateral relations</a>, they also discussed the controversial <a href="/wiki/Migration_Act_1958" title="Migration Act 1958">Section 501 deportation policy</a>. Albanese confirmed that <a href="/wiki/Albanese_government" title="Albanese government">his government</a> would amend the deportation policy to take into account individuals' connections to Australia and the length of time they had lived in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">&#91;176&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">&#91;177&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Australian_PM_Anthony_Albanese_and_Indian_PM_Narendra_Modi.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Australian_PM_Anthony_Albanese_and_Indian_PM_Narendra_Modi.jpg/220px-Australian_PM_Anthony_Albanese_and_Indian_PM_Narendra_Modi.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="202" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Australian_PM_Anthony_Albanese_and_Indian_PM_Narendra_Modi.jpg/330px-Australian_PM_Anthony_Albanese_and_Indian_PM_Narendra_Modi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Australian_PM_Anthony_Albanese_and_Indian_PM_Narendra_Modi.jpg/440px-Australian_PM_Anthony_Albanese_and_Indian_PM_Narendra_Modi.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1878" /></a><figcaption>Albanese with the Indian PM Narendra Modi at the <a href="/wiki/75_Years_of_Friendship_through_Cricket_Event" title="75 Years of Friendship through Cricket Event">75 Years of Friendship through Cricket Event</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>In March 2023, Albanese visited India to attend the Australia-India Annual Leaders' Summit in New Dehli. During the visit, he also led a trade delegation, which included Trade Minister <a href="/wiki/Don_Farrell" title="Don Farrell">Don Farrell</a> and Resources Minister <a href="/wiki/Madeleine_King" title="Madeleine King">Madeleine King</a>, after the implementation of the Economic Cooperation and Trade Agreement (ECTA) between Australia and India on 29 December 2022. He also attended the <a href="/wiki/75_Years_of_Friendship_through_Cricket_Event" title="75 Years of Friendship through Cricket Event">75 Years of Friendship through Cricket Event</a> hosted by PM Modi at the <a href="/wiki/Narendra_Modi_Stadium" title="Narendra Modi Stadium">Narendra Modi Stadium</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ahmedabad" title="Ahmedabad">Ahmedabad</a> to celebrate 75 years of strong diplomatic and cricketing ties between the two nations. The PMs attended a match of the <a href="/wiki/Border-Gavaskar_Trophy" class="mw-redirect" title="Border-Gavaskar Trophy">Border-Gavaskar Trophy</a> where Albanese handed over Australian Cricket Captain <a href="/wiki/Steve_Smith_(cricketer)" title="Steve Smith (cricketer)">Steve Smith</a> his test cap.
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:19.05.2023_-_Encontro_com_o_Primeiro-Ministro_da_Comunidade_da_Austr%C3%A1lia,_Anthony_Albanese_(52909315146).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/19.05.2023_-_Encontro_com_o_Primeiro-Ministro_da_Comunidade_da_Austr%C3%A1lia%2C_Anthony_Albanese_%2852909315146%29.jpg/220px-19.05.2023_-_Encontro_com_o_Primeiro-Ministro_da_Comunidade_da_Austr%C3%A1lia%2C_Anthony_Albanese_%2852909315146%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/19.05.2023_-_Encontro_com_o_Primeiro-Ministro_da_Comunidade_da_Austr%C3%A1lia%2C_Anthony_Albanese_%2852909315146%29.jpg/330px-19.05.2023_-_Encontro_com_o_Primeiro-Ministro_da_Comunidade_da_Austr%C3%A1lia%2C_Anthony_Albanese_%2852909315146%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/19.05.2023_-_Encontro_com_o_Primeiro-Ministro_da_Comunidade_da_Austr%C3%A1lia%2C_Anthony_Albanese_%2852909315146%29.jpg/440px-19.05.2023_-_Encontro_com_o_Primeiro-Ministro_da_Comunidade_da_Austr%C3%A1lia%2C_Anthony_Albanese_%2852909315146%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3984" data-file-height="2656" /></a><figcaption>Albanese (left) with Brazilian president <a href="/wiki/Luiz_In%C3%A1cio_Lula_da_Silva" title="Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva">Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva</a> (right) at the <a href="/wiki/49th_G7_summit" title="49th G7 summit">49th G7 summit</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>On 13 March 2023, Albanese travelled to San Diego to officially commence the <a href="/wiki/AUKUS" title="AUKUS">AUKUS</a> security pact with President Biden and United Kingdom prime minister <a href="/wiki/Rishi_Sunak" title="Rishi Sunak">Rishi Sunak</a>. Through the deal, which was signed by Albanese's predecessor, Australia will procure $368 billion worth of defence materiel, including <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_submarines" class="mw-redirect" title="Nuclear submarines">nuclear-powered submarines</a> in an effort to counter China's dominance in the Indo-Pacific region.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">&#91;178&#93;</a></sup> The deal has been negatively received by China<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">&#91;179&#93;</a></sup> and former prime minister <a href="/wiki/Paul_Keating" title="Paul Keating">Paul Keating</a>, who called it the "worst deal in all history".<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">&#91;180&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Anthony_Albanese_and_Bongbong_Marcos_4.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Anthony_Albanese_and_Bongbong_Marcos_4.jpg/220px-Anthony_Albanese_and_Bongbong_Marcos_4.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Anthony_Albanese_and_Bongbong_Marcos_4.jpg/330px-Anthony_Albanese_and_Bongbong_Marcos_4.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Anthony_Albanese_and_Bongbong_Marcos_4.jpg/440px-Anthony_Albanese_and_Bongbong_Marcos_4.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1350" data-file-height="899" /></a><figcaption>Albanese with Filipino President <a href="/wiki/Bongbong_Marcos" title="Bongbong Marcos">Bongbong Marcos</a> during his visit in <a href="/wiki/Manila" title="Manila">Manila</a></figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="/wiki/Australia%E2%80%93Philippines_relations" title="Australia–Philippines relations">Australia–Philippines relations</a> upgraded to a <a href="/wiki/Strategic_alliance" title="Strategic alliance">strategic partnership</a> when Albanese visited <a href="/wiki/Manila" title="Manila">Manila</a> on 8 September 2023, the first bilateral visit to the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a> by an Australian prime minister in two decades. He and President <a href="/wiki/Bongbong_Marcos" title="Bongbong Marcos">Bongbong Marcos</a> agreed for their <a href="/wiki/Defence_minister" class="mw-redirect" title="Defence minister">defence ministers</a> to meet annually due to "rising security challenges" in the Indo-Pacific.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">&#91;181&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Between 4 and 7 November, Albanese visited <a href="/wiki/Shanghai" title="Shanghai">Shanghai</a> and <a href="/wiki/Beijing" title="Beijing">Beijing</a>, becoming the first Australian prime minister to visit China in seven years.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">&#91;182&#93;</a></sup> The trip, described as an effort to get relations between Australia and China on track, coincided with the 50th anniversary of Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Gough_Whitlam" title="Gough Whitlam">Gough Whitlam</a>'s visit to China, the first by an Australian prime minister.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">&#91;183&#93;</a></sup> During the trip, Albanese gave a speech at the <a href="/wiki/China_International_Import_Expo" title="China International Import Expo">China International Import Expo</a>, and met with Premier <a href="/wiki/Li_Qiang" title="Li Qiang">Li Qiang</a> and President Xi Jinping.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">&#91;184&#93;</a></sup> The following week, he signed the Falepili Union treaty with the Pacific island country of <a href="/wiki/Tuvalu" title="Tuvalu">Tuvalu</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">&#91;185&#93;</a></sup> Described as "groundbreaking" by legal schloar <a href="/wiki/Jane_McAdam" title="Jane McAdam">Jane McAdam</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">&#91;186&#93;</a></sup> the treaty entrenches <a href="/wiki/Australia%E2%80%93Tuvalu_relations" title="Australia–Tuvalu relations">bilateral relations</a> between the two countries, with Australia agreeing to provide funds to help the country deal with the effects of climate change and also resettle 280 Tuvaluans a year, as the country is particularly vulnerable to the effects of <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Tuvalu" title="Climate change in Tuvalu">climate change</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">&#91;187&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_views">Political views</span></h2>
<p>Albanese has described his political views as <a href="/wiki/Progressivism" title="Progressivism">progressive</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">&#91;188&#93;</a></sup> and is aligned with the <a href="/wiki/Labor_Left" title="Labor Left">Labor Left</a> faction.<sup id="cite_ref-Conversation_190-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Conversation-190">&#91;189&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">&#91;190&#93;</a></sup> Several journalists and analysts have noted his ideological shift to <a href="/wiki/Centrist_politics" class="mw-redirect" title="Centrist politics">centrism</a> during the 2022 election campaign and upon becoming prime minister.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">&#91;191&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">&#91;192&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">&#91;193&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Albanese is a <a href="/wiki/Republicanism_in_Australia" title="Republicanism in Australia">republican</a>, and supports replacing Australia's current <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_Australia" title="Monarchy of Australia">constitutional monarchy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">&#91;194&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">&#91;195&#93;</a></sup> In a debate to mark the <a href="/wiki/Platinum_Jubilee_of_Elizabeth_II#Australia" title="Platinum Jubilee of Elizabeth II">Queen's Platinum Jubilee</a>, he told the Australian Parliament, "Even many Australians who do not hold with the principle of monarchy feel regard for her. You can be a republican, as I am, and still have the deepest respect for the Queen. She has done her duty with fidelity, integrity, humanity and, as she sometimes lets slip, a sly sense of humour."<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">&#91;196&#93;</a></sup> He has stated his desire to give <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_recognition_of_Indigenous_Australians" title="Constitutional recognition of Indigenous Australians">constitutional recognition</a> to <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_Australians" title="Indigenous Australians">Indigenous Australians</a>, and pledged to hold a referendum regarding an <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_Voice_to_Parliament" title="Indigenous Voice to Parliament">Indigenous Voice to Parliament</a> upon becoming prime minister.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">&#91;197&#93;</a></sup> He has stated that this recognition should come before any referendum regarding Australia's status as a constitutional monarchy vs. a republic.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_199-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-199">&#91;198&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environmental_issues">Environmental issues</span></h3>
<p>While serving in the <a href="/wiki/Gillard_government" title="Gillard government">Gillard government</a>, Albanese supported the introduction of <a href="/wiki/Carbon_pricing" class="mw-redirect" title="Carbon pricing">carbon pricing</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">&#91;199&#93;</a></sup> and voted, along with the rest of the Labor Party, to establish the <i><a href="/wiki/Clean_Energy_Act_2011" title="Clean Energy Act 2011">Clean Energy Act 2011</a></i>, which instituted a <a href="/wiki/Carbon_pricing_in_Australia" title="Carbon pricing in Australia">carbon pricing scheme in Australia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">&#91;200&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">&#91;201&#93;</a></sup> After the <a href="/wiki/Abbott_government" title="Abbott government">Abbott government</a> abolished the scheme in July 2014,<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">&#91;202&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">&#91;203&#93;</a></sup> Albanese stated that carbon pricing was no longer needed, as "the circumstances have changed".<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">&#91;204&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">&#91;205&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Albanese is a prominent backer of <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_in_Australia" title="Renewable energy in Australia">renewable energy in Australia</a> and has declared that the country's "long-term future lies in renewable energy sources".<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">&#91;206&#93;</a></sup> Upon his election in 2022, he said he would "end the <a href="/wiki/Climate_wars" class="mw-redirect" title="Climate wars">climate wars</a>" and mitigation and policies to address <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Australia" title="Climate change in Australia">climate change in Australia</a> would be a priority for his government, in contrast with those preceding it.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">&#91;207&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_policy">Foreign policy</span></h3>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:20230521outreach_061.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/20230521outreach_061.jpg/252px-20230521outreach_061.jpg" decoding="async" width="252" height="183" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/20230521outreach_061.jpg/378px-20230521outreach_061.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/20230521outreach_061.jpg/504px-20230521outreach_061.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2600" data-file-height="1887" /></a><figcaption>Albanese with <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Japan" title="Prime Minister of Japan">Japanese Prime Minister</a> <a href="/wiki/Fumio_Kishida" title="Fumio Kishida">Fumio Kishida</a>, in 2023</figcaption></figure>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:NATO_Summit,_Vilnius.P061598-844404.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/NATO_Summit%2C_Vilnius.P061598-844404.jpg/252px-NATO_Summit%2C_Vilnius.P061598-844404.jpg" decoding="async" width="252" height="168" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/NATO_Summit%2C_Vilnius.P061598-844404.jpg/378px-NATO_Summit%2C_Vilnius.P061598-844404.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/NATO_Summit%2C_Vilnius.P061598-844404.jpg/504px-NATO_Summit%2C_Vilnius.P061598-844404.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6124" data-file-height="4082" /></a><figcaption>Albanese with European Commission President <a href="/wiki/Ursula_von_der_Leyen" title="Ursula von der Leyen">Ursula von der Leyen</a> in <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> Summit in <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">Vilnius</a>, Lithuania, in 2023</figcaption></figure>
<p>Albanese's foreign policy beliefs have been the subject of media attention. Writing for the <i><a href="/wiki/Australian_Financial_Review" title="Australian Financial Review">Australian Financial Review</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/James_Curran_(linguist)" title="James Curran (linguist)">James Curran</a> noted his shift from an "idealistic left-wing critic of globalisation" to "a true believer in the American alliance".<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">&#91;208&#93;</a></sup> Albanese was staunchly opposed to the US-led <a href="/wiki/2003_invasion_of_Iraq" title="2003 invasion of Iraq">invasion of Iraq</a>, saying in February 2003 that "Whatever criticisms can be made of the Iraqi regime, Islamic fundamentalism is not one of them. This is one of the reasons the United States supported Saddam Hussein in the 1980s, including supplying his regime with weapons of mass destruction, which he then used against both the Iranians and the Kurds."<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">&#91;209&#93;</a></sup> Albanese has repeatedly urged for the release of Australian whistleblower and <a href="/wiki/WikiLeaks" title="WikiLeaks">WikiLeaks</a> founder <a href="/wiki/Julian_Assange" title="Julian Assange">Julian Assange</a>, who is currently being held in custody in the United Kingdom.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">&#91;210&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Albanese's views on the <a href="/wiki/Israeli%E2%80%93Palestinian_conflict" title="Israeli–Palestinian conflict">Israeli–Palestinian conflict</a> have also been the subject of media interest, with <i><a href="/wiki/The_Times_of_Israel" title="The Times of Israel">The Times of Israel</a></i> categorising him as a supporter of Palestine.<sup id="cite_ref-TOI_212-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TOI-212">&#91;211&#93;</a></sup> Alongside <a href="/wiki/Joe_Hockey" title="Joe Hockey">Joe Hockey</a>, Albanese established the parliamentary "Friends of Palestine" group in 1998.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">&#91;212&#93;</a></sup> Despite this, he has been a critic of the <a href="/wiki/Boycott,_Divestment_and_Sanctions" title="Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions">Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions</a> movement, calling it "clumsy and counterproductive".<sup id="cite_ref-TOI_212-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TOI-212">&#91;211&#93;</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/2014_Gaza_War" title="2014 Gaza War">2014 Gaza War</a>, he called Israel's bombardment of the <a href="/wiki/Gaza_Strip" title="Gaza Strip">Gaza Strip</a> a "collective punishment" that was "completely unacceptable".<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">&#91;213&#93;</a></sup> In 2018, he challenged a decision by the Australian government to vote against a UN human rights council motion calling for an investigation into the killings of Palestinian protesters during the <a href="/wiki/2018%E2%80%932019_Gaza_border_protests" title="2018–2019 Gaza border protests">Great March of Return</a>. Shortly before the 2022 election, Albanese told <i><a href="/wiki/The_Australian_Jewish_News" title="The Australian Jewish News">The Australian Jewish News</a></i> that any decision he takes on Israel-Palestine will contribute "to a peaceful resolution of the conflict and to progress towards a <a href="/wiki/Two-state_solution" title="Two-state solution">two-state solution</a>". When asked about a 2018 resolution to <a href="/wiki/International_recognition_of_the_State_of_Palestine" title="International recognition of the State of Palestine">recognise</a> the <a href="/wiki/State_of_Palestine" title="State of Palestine">State of Palestine</a>, Albanese insisted the motion "has no greater or lesser weight" than it did previously.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">&#91;214&#93;</a></sup> In October 2022, his government reversed the Morrison government's decision to recognise <a href="/wiki/West_Jerusalem" title="West Jerusalem">West Jerusalem</a> as Israel's capital.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">&#91;215&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">&#91;216&#93;</a></sup> In December 2023, Albanese signed a joint statement, along with the prime ministers of Canada and New Zealand, calling for a ceasefire in the <a href="/wiki/2023_Israel%E2%80%93Hamas_war" class="mw-redirect" title="2023 Israel–Hamas war">2023 Israel–Hamas war</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">&#91;217&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">&#91;218&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In February 2022, Albanese condemned <a href="/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">Russia's invasion of Ukraine</a>, remarking in a press release that it was a "grave moment for humanity".<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">&#91;219&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 2022, Albanese said Australia's relationship with <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> would remain "a difficult one".<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">&#91;220&#93;</a></sup> He said that "Australia values human rights. We have spoken out about the <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Uyghurs_in_China" title="Persecution of Uyghurs in China">treatment of Uyghurs</a>, about what's occurred in Hong Kong, about Taiwan, about other minorities including in Tibet, that are suffering from human rights abuses."<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">&#91;221&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Social_issues">Social issues</span></h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:AAlbanese.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/AAlbanese.jpg/170px-AAlbanese.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="227" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/AAlbanese.jpg/255px-AAlbanese.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/AAlbanese.jpg/340px-AAlbanese.jpg 2x" data-file-width="960" data-file-height="1280" /></a><figcaption>Albanese at the <a href="/wiki/Sydney_Gay_and_Lesbian_Mardi_Gras" title="Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras">Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras</a> in 2003</figcaption></figure>
<p>Albanese supports <a href="/wiki/Abortion_rights" class="mw-redirect" title="Abortion rights">abortion rights</a>, stating in an interview in August 2019 that he believes "women do have a right to choose".<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">&#91;222&#93;</a></sup> He is also in favour of legalising <a href="/wiki/Voluntary_euthanasia" title="Voluntary euthanasia">voluntary euthanasia</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">&#91;223&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">&#91;224&#93;</a></sup> in December 2022, his government repealed the <i><a href="/wiki/Euthanasia_Laws_Act_1997" title="Euthanasia Laws Act 1997">Euthanasia Laws Act 1997</a></i>, which prevented the <a href="/wiki/States_and_territories_of_Australia" title="States and territories of Australia">territories of Australia</a> from legalising euthanasia.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">&#91;225&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Albanese is a supporter and advocate for <a href="/wiki/LGBT" title="LGBT">LGBT</a> rights,<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">&#91;226&#93;</a></sup> and has regularly participated in the <a href="/wiki/Sydney_Gay_and_Lesbian_Mardi_Gras" title="Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras">Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras</a> since 1983.<sup id="cite_ref-Conversation_190-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Conversation-190">&#91;189&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">&#91;227&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">&#91;228&#93;</a></sup> When Labor Party members were granted a <a href="/wiki/Conscience_vote" title="Conscience vote">conscience vote</a> on the <i>Marriage Amendment Bill 2012</i>, which would have legalised same-sex marriage in Australia, Albanese voted in favour of the bill, which was unsuccessful.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">&#91;229&#93;</a></sup> He opposed <a href="/wiki/Australian_Marriage_Law_Postal_Survey" title="Australian Marriage Law Postal Survey">holding a plebiscite for same-sex marriage</a>, stating that "we shouldn't be having a public vote where we get to judge other families".<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">&#91;230&#93;</a></sup> In 2017, Albanese also voted in favour of the <i><a href="/wiki/Marriage_Amendment_(Definition_and_Religious_Freedoms)_Act_2017" title="Marriage Amendment (Definition and Religious Freedoms) Act 2017">Marriage Amendment (Definition and Religious Freedoms) Act 2017</a></i>, the bill which ultimately legalised same-sex marriage.<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">&#91;231&#93;</a></sup> Albanese has voiced support of transgender rights, saying that "people coming to terms with their identity and who they are, I think that they need to be respected."<sup id="cite_ref-:0_199-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-199">&#91;198&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Early in his political career, Albanese supported <a href="/wiki/Drug_liberalization" title="Drug liberalization">drug decriminalisation</a>, telling Parliament in 1997 that "drug use by individuals is a health issue, not a criminal issue".<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">&#91;232&#93;</a></sup> However, in February 2022, he declined to commit to decriminalisation of <a href="/wiki/Hard_drugs" class="mw-redirect" title="Hard drugs">hard drugs</a>, commenting that the "current settings are appropriate".<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">&#91;233&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In July 2015, Albanese stated his opposition to the government's policy of turning back <a href="/wiki/Asylum_seeker" title="Asylum seeker">asylum seekers</a> who arrive to the country via boat, saying: "I couldn't ask someone else to do something that I couldn't see myself doing ... if people were in a boat including families and children, I myself couldn't turn that around."<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">&#91;234&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">&#91;235&#93;</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/2022_Australian_federal_election" title="2022 Australian federal election">2022 federal election</a> campaign, Albanese clarified that boat turnbacks would be incorporated into his government's policy,<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">&#91;236&#93;</a></sup> leading to some critics accusing him of "flip-flopping" on the issue.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">&#91;237&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">&#91;238&#93;</a></sup> In August 2021, after the <a href="/wiki/2021_Taliban_offensive" title="2021 Taliban offensive">Taliban seized control</a> of <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>, Albanese urged the <a href="/wiki/Morrison_government" title="Morrison government">Morrison government</a> to give <a href="/wiki/Afghan_refugees" title="Afghan refugees">Afghan refugees</a> permanent residency in Australia.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">&#91;239&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Personal_life">Personal life</span></h2>
<p>In 2000, Albanese married <a href="/wiki/Carmel_Tebbutt" title="Carmel Tebbutt">Carmel Tebbutt</a>, a future <a href="/wiki/Deputy_Premier_of_New_South_Wales" title="Deputy Premier of New South Wales">Deputy Premier of New South Wales</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">&#91;240&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">&#91;241&#93;</a></sup> They had met in Young Labor during the late 1980s,<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">&#91;242&#93;</a></sup> and have one son together.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">&#91;243&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">&#91;244&#93;</a></sup> The two separated in January 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">&#91;245&#93;</a></sup> In June 2020, it was reported that Albanese was in a relationship<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">&#91;246&#93;</a></sup> with <a href="/wiki/Jodie_Haydon" title="Jodie Haydon">Jodie Haydon</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">&#91;247&#93;</a></sup> Albanese said they had met at a dinner event in Melbourne a year after his separation from Tebbutt.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">&#91;248&#93;</a></sup> Albanese is the first divorcee to be appointed prime minister.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">&#91;249&#93;</a></sup> In February 2024, Albanese announced his engagement to Haydon after proposing to her at <a href="/wiki/The_Lodge,_Australia" title="The Lodge, Australia">The Lodge</a> in <a href="/wiki/Canberra" title="Canberra">Canberra</a>, making him the first prime minister of Australia to be engaged while in office.<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">&#91;250&#93;</a></sup> 
</p><p>Albanese describes himself as "half-Italian and half-Irish"<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">&#91;251&#93;</a></sup> and a "non-practising Catholic".<sup id="cite_ref-catholic_253-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-catholic-253">&#91;252&#93;</a></sup> He is also a music fan who, not long after becoming prime minister, attended a <a href="/wiki/Gang_of_Youths" title="Gang of Youths">Gang of Youths</a> concert at the <a href="/wiki/Enmore_Theatre" title="Enmore Theatre">Enmore Theatre</a><sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">&#91;253&#93;</a></sup> and previously intervened as transport minister to save a <a href="/wiki/Dolly_Parton" title="Dolly Parton">Dolly Parton</a> tour from bureaucratic red tape.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">&#91;254&#93;</a></sup> In 2013, he co-hosted a pre-election special of music program <i><a href="/wiki/Rage_(TV_program)" title="Rage (TV program)">Rage</a></i> and his song selection included the <a href="/wiki/Pixies_(band)" title="Pixies (band)">Pixies</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Pogues" title="The Pogues">the Pogues</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Smiths" title="The Smiths">the Smiths</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Triffids" title="The Triffids">the Triffids</a>, <a href="/wiki/PJ_Harvey" title="PJ Harvey">PJ Harvey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nirvana_(band)" title="Nirvana (band)">Nirvana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hunters_%26_Collectors" title="Hunters &amp; Collectors">Hunters &amp; Collectors</a> and <a href="/wiki/Joy_Division" title="Joy Division">Joy Division</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">&#91;255&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">&#91;256&#93;</a></sup> On 30 November 2023, Albanese posted his <a href="/wiki/Spotify_Wrapped" title="Spotify Wrapped">Spotify Wrapped</a> to his <a href="/wiki/Instagram_story" class="mw-redirect" title="Instagram story">Instagram story</a>, indicating his top artists to be <a href="/wiki/Lana_Del_Rey" title="Lana Del Rey">Lana Del Rey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taylor_Swift" title="Taylor Swift">Taylor Swift</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hilltop_Hoods" title="Hilltop Hoods">Hilltop Hoods</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bruce_Springsteen" title="Bruce Springsteen">Bruce Springsteen</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Lily_Allen" title="Lily Allen">Lily Allen</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">&#91;257&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>As a lifelong supporter of the <a href="/wiki/South_Sydney_Rabbitohs" title="South Sydney Rabbitohs">South Sydney Rabbitohs</a> rugby league club, he was a board member of the club from 1999 to 2002 and influential in the fight to have the club readmitted to the <a href="/wiki/National_Rugby_League" title="National Rugby League">National Rugby League</a> (NRL) competition.<sup id="cite_ref-souths_259-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-souths-259">&#91;258&#93;</a></sup> During October 2009, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Sydney_Morning_Herald" title="The Sydney Morning Herald">The Sydney Morning Herald</a></i> reported that Albanese had opposed an attempt to appoint the former Liberal prime minister <a href="/wiki/John_Howard" title="John Howard">John Howard</a> to a senior position in the NRL. Albanese stated he had phoned the NRL chief executive, <a href="/wiki/David_Gallop" title="David Gallop">David Gallop</a>, as well as other league officials, to advise them against the idea. He then implored officials at Souths to help stop the suggestion from gaining momentum.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">&#91;259&#93;</a></sup> In 2013, he was made a life member of the club.<sup id="cite_ref-souths_259-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-souths-259">&#91;258&#93;</a></sup> He is also a fan of <a href="/wiki/Australian_rules_football" title="Australian rules football">Australian rules football</a>, and supports the <a href="/wiki/Hawthorn_Football_Club" title="Hawthorn Football Club">Hawthorn Football Club</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">&#91;260&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">&#91;261&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Albanese was injured in a <a href="/wiki/Side_collision" title="Side collision">side collision</a> while driving in <a href="/wiki/Marrickville,_New_South_Wales" title="Marrickville, New South Wales">Marrickville, New South Wales</a>, on 8 January 2021. He underwent treatment at <a href="/wiki/Royal_Prince_Alfred_Hospital" title="Royal Prince Alfred Hospital">Royal Prince Alfred Hospital</a> and was reportedly "injured externally and internally and had suffered considerable shock in the immediate aftermath of the impact". The other driver was a 17-year-old who received a ticket for negligent driving.<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">&#91;262&#93;</a></sup> Emergency workers told Albanese that if the teen's car had hit just 30 centimetres either side of where it did, Albanese "would almost certainly have been killed".<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">&#91;263&#93;</a></sup> Shortly following this accident, Albanese lost over 18 kilograms (39 pounds) by cutting out carbohydrates and reducing his alcohol intake, in an effort to be "match fit" for his election campaign.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">&#91;264&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">&#91;265&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1217336898">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Both pronunciations have been used by Albanese himself during his life; they are both in common use among other speakers. While Albanese always used <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="/æ/: &#39;a&#39; in &#39;bad&#39;">æ</span><span title="&#39;l&#39; in &#39;lie&#39;">l</span><span title="&#39;b&#39; in &#39;buy&#39;">b</span><span title="/ə/: &#39;a&#39; in &#39;about&#39;">ə</span><span title="&#39;n&#39; in &#39;nigh&#39;">n</span><span title="/iː/: &#39;ee&#39; in &#39;fleece&#39;">iː</span><span title="&#39;z&#39; in &#39;zoom&#39;">z</span></span>/</a></span></span> throughout his early life,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiddleton2016240_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiddleton2016240-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> he has more recently been heard using <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˌ/: secondary stress follows">ˌ</span><span title="/æ/: &#39;a&#39; in &#39;bad&#39;">æ</span><span title="&#39;l&#39; in &#39;lie&#39;">l</span><span title="&#39;b&#39; in &#39;buy&#39;">b</span><span title="/ə/: &#39;a&#39; in &#39;about&#39;">ə</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="&#39;n&#39; in &#39;nigh&#39;">n</span><span title="/iː/: &#39;ee&#39; in &#39;fleece&#39;">iː</span><span title="&#39;z&#39; in &#39;zoom&#39;">z</span><span title="/i/: &#39;y&#39; in &#39;happy&#39;">i</span></span>/</a></span></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>
